Conservation measures proposed for India include: 1) extend the Great Himalayan National Park as proposed, 2) establish the proposed Srikhand National Park (Himachal Pradesh), 3) devise innovative community based reserves for the species outside protected areas (these need to include community based protection, tourism, awareness, etc.), and 4) include areas with tahr in the innovative, participatory, landscape level planning and action under the Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change, Project Snow Leopard. Overall, the country’s conservation strategy clearly states conserving species in and outside protected areas.

A significant proportion of Nepal’s tahr occurs within protected areas, but its population is widespread in areas outside of protected areas (e.g., the region that lies between Manaslu and Langtang, Bhimthang valley between Manalsu and Annapurna, and Dolpo, Jumla, Mugu and Humla districts). The species occurs in all mountain protected areas of Nepal: Langtang, Rara, Sagamartha (Everest), Makalu-Barun and Shey-Phoksundo National Parks; Api Nampa, Annapurna, Manalsu, Gaurishankar and Kanchanjunga Conservation Areas, Dhorpatan Hunting Reserve, and Khaptad National Park.

Conservation measures proposed for Nepal: 1) maintain the current, closely controlled, legal hunting program in Dhorpatan, 2) consider a regulated program of low-level subsistence hunting by local villagers, and 3) undertake surveys to understand the increasing fragmentation of tahr populations and offer mitigation measures. The first steps to address this issue would be to begin in selected areas by mapping tahr habitat features such as cliffs (using 1:50,000 topographic maps), followed by ground surveys to validate the species’ presence/absence.

Dhorpatan Hunting Reserve is the only reserve in Nepal that allows trophy hunting of Himalayan Tahr along with blue sheep. From 2008 to 2011, Karki and Thapa (2011) reported 34 Himalayan Tahr were harvested: 18 in 2008/09 (100% harvest; quota set by the government), 11 (61% in 2009/10) and 5 (28 % in 2010/11). A quick glance on the numbers harvested indicates they were not so small numbers if adult males have been the only target. It would mean some 10-15 % of the adult male (trophy) population (Sandro Lovari, pers. comm). Perhaps the Department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation – Nepal should consider revaluating the trophy hunting of tahr on a sustainable basis.

rationale: This species is assessed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 4,650 km², all individuals are in fewer than five locations (essentially a single location), and there is continuing decline in extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, the extent and quality of its habitat, and presumably the number of mature individuals.
habitat: It is found on cold, wet slopes of montane forest with numerous epiphytes, mosses, and fallen trees. Its biology is poorly known (Reid 1997).
threats: The main threat to this species is the significant forest loss in its habitat. Habitat fragmentation, landslides, and floods are additional threats.
population: This rodent is rare and local (Reid 1997).
range: This species is known only from southeastern Chiapas (Mexico) and bordering parts of western Guatemala (Patton 2005). It is found from 2,500 to 2,800 m (Reid 1997). The Guatemalan population may have been severely affected  by Hurricane Stan in 2006.
conservationActions: This species occurs in a newly-named national park, Tacana, in Mexico.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, occurrence in a number of protected areas, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: The species is fossorial and is found in open steppe habitat with loose soil not sand. It has been recoded from cultivated fields though it can live in shallow mountainside soils, where it burrows, feeding on the underground parts of plants. It does not hibernate but may become inactive in the summer. The reproductive period is short. Females produces three embryos.
threats: There are no major threats to this species as a whole. In southern Turkmenistan, the habitat is being degraded in some areas by agriculture. In South Asia it is threatened by natural calamities such as drought, wildfires, avalanches and landslides and interspecific competitors (Molur et al. 2005).
population: The species is common in suitable habitats. It is uncommon in Turkmenistan.
range: This widespread species ranges from eastern Iran, through Turkmenistan and Afghanistan, east to Pakistan  (Habibi 2003, Shenbrot and Krasnov 2005). It ranges from 300-400 m to 2400 m.
conservationActions: This species is present in many protected areas. No direct conservation measures as a whole are currently needed for this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because while its extent of occurrence is much greater than 20,000 km², its area of occupancy is estimated to be around 2,500 km² and the extent and quality of its habitat are probably declining and are severely fragmented, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under criterion B2ab(iii).
habitat:
This species occurs in subaquatic environments and cloud forests. It is found in areas with a constant flow of well oxygenated water. This species is mostly nocturnal and is a carnivore. It's diet consists of snails, insects, frogs and fish (Ceballos 2014).

In El Salvador, foods eaten include insects, birds, salamanders, mammals (possibly another Rheomys), and starchy pulp (Stirton 1944). One individual from Guatemala had eaten stonefly and mayfly larvae, beetles, and part of a catfish (Hooper 1968). A captive mouse readily consumed small fish and aquatic insect larvae (Reid 1997).
threats: A major threat to this species is its fragile environment <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species biggest threat is its very fraile habitat (Ceballos 2014)"}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":515,"3":{"1":0},"4":{"1":2,"2":14275305},"12":0}">(Ceballos 2014). Stream degradation and water quality degradation are major threats due to its reliance on stream habitats. Other potential threats include landslides.
population: It is uncommon and local (Reid 1997). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species has a small population (Ceballos 2014)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":513,"3":{"1":0},"12":0}">This species has a small population (Ceballos 2014).
range: This species occurs in the highlands of south México (Chiapas), Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras (Musser and Carleton 2005). It is found from 400 m to 2,700 m (Reid 1997).
conservationActions: This species occurs in  El Triunfo Biosphere Reserve in Mexico and in El Imposible National Park in El Salvador.

rationale: This species has been listed as Vulnerable D2 because the species is found in a single location, Camiguin Island, where there is forest loss at lower elevations, which might extend to higher elevations in the future.
habitat: The species occurs in montane and mossy forest and areas which are subject to natural disturbance caused by volcanoes and landslides, there is little or no old growth forest here because of this disturbance. It is possible that the species remains in lower elevation habitats, including disturbed areas (L. Heaney pers. comm). It has been reported at an elevation range from 900 m to 1,475 m (Rickart et al. 2002).
threats: If the species remains in lower elevation areas, it may be affected by habitat loss due to slash and burn agriculture, logging, urbanization and increased tourism; it is less threatened at higher elevation areas where logging and deforestation occur to a lesser degree and areas of intact forest remain (L. Heaney pers. comm. 2006).
population: The population is likely to comprise of less than 10,000 individuals (L. Heaney pers. comm. 2006). This is a relatively common in suitable habitat (L. Heaney pers. comm.), but it occurs at lower densities than Apomys camiguinensis which is tolerant of a wider range of habitats.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines and is restricted to Camiguin island (Heaney et al. 1998). It has been recorded from 900 m to 1,475 m asl. (Rickart et al. 2002).
conservationActions: The species is found in Timboong Hibok-hibok Natural Monument.

rationale: The species appears to be restricted to a small area (area of occupancy (AOO) = 8 km²), representing one location. A massive landslide occurred in the year 2000, which considerably disturbed the habitat of this fish.  After this event, agrochemical use in the area has decreased the habitat  quality, and channelling of the river led to changes in water levels. The species was not observed in a survey performed in 2010, and locals reported not having seen it after the landslide. Hence, it is listed as Critically Endangered. Further field studies are urgently needed to evaluate whether the species may be extinct.
habitat: This species inhabits high altitude small rivers. Little additional information is available on the natural history of this species. The habitat is suffering continuing decline due to pollution from agricultural activities.
threats: A massive landslide disturbed the habitat of this fish in the year 2000. After this event, agrochemical use for agriculture in the area has modified the quality of the habitat, and channeling of the river led to changes in water levels (M. Velasquez pers. comm. 2014).
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. In a survey performed in 2010 the species was not observed, and locals reported not having seen it in the past 10 years (M. Velasquez pers. comm. 2014). Due to natural events (landslide) and anthropogenic threats, it is suspected that the population of this species has declined in the past 10 years (M. Velasquez pers. comm. 2014). It is estimated that three generations of this species is less than 10 years.
range: This species occurs in the Ucayali River basin in Peru. Its type locality is a small brook in highlands, South East of Tarma, Queta (Eigenmann 1913). Its AOO has been estimated to be approximately 8 km² (a stretch of river of 8 km in length by 1 km wide), and it is assumed to occur at only one location, based on the main threat to the species (pollution from agrochemicals).
useTrade: The species is not utilized.
conservationActions: The species does not occur in any protected area. Additional surveys within the known range and adjacent areas are needed to identify remaining populations of this species.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because this once abundant species has not recuperated from a drastic population decline, inferred from the apparent disappearance of most of the population possibly due to chytridiomycosis in the 1990s. Also, the species is affected by a continuous habitat loss and degradation due to agriculture, landslides, fires, logging, human settlements, among other threats occurring throughout its range, and areas that it may possibly be found. If a population still exists it is thought to have fewer than 50 mature individuals, and it is tagged as 'Possibly Extinct' as it has not been recorded since 1996.
habitat: This species lives in premontane and lower montane wet forest, and is found breeding in clear water, steep and fast-flowing mountain streams. It is not tolerant to habitat disturbance.
threats:
Chytridiomycosis is thought to be a threat to this species, and it is suspected that it caused the population declines that have been observed. Habitat loss and degradation are also problems. In Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, the area from which this species was recorded is subject to extensive landslides which often severely impact the species' habitat. The type locality for this species has been completely destroyed by landslides. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, mining activity to extract antimony at the locality where this species has been found, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core parts both the Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Texiguat, which may create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez, J. Ramos Galdámez and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is also increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabitat a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population:
The species was previously abundant up until 1989, when it was suspected that chytridiomycosis had caused major population declines. According to McCranie and Castañeda (2007), the last species of the type locality were observed in February 1995, while the tadpoles were last observed in the year 1996.

There were surveys in Texiguat: one in 2008, two surveys in 2010, two surveys in 2011, one survey in March 2018, one in December 2018, and one in Feb 2019, all of which have not recorded the species after searching all suitable elevations in that locality (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). It is considered to be extinct from both localities that it has been recorded from, however it may occur in the interior area of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and in other areas of suitable habitat within Texiguat (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). If a population of this species exists, then it is reasonable to assume that is small, as the areas where it may possibly exist are small, and would contain less than 50 individuals.
range: This species is known from the middle and eastern of the Cordillera Nombre de Dios along the Atlantic versant of north-central Honduras, between 750-1,760 m asl. It is only known from two sites, that are 60 km apart. It may occur in the interior area of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and in other areas of suitable habitat within Texiguat (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019), but surveys are required for verification. The two known localities are coded as 'Possibly Extinct' in its distribution map, as it has not been seen in over 20 years there, and suitable elevations in both Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Texiguat have been included but coded as 'Possibly Extant' and are excluded from the extent of occurrence (EOO) calculation. Its EOO is 190 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). A captive-breeding programme is recommended, should individuals of this species be found (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). 

Research Needed
Research is urgently needed to determine whether or not this species has been affected by chytridiomycosis. Further populations surveys are required at both sites to determine whether the species is surviving in those areas (Honduras Assessment Workshop March 2019).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Near Threatened because although this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of XXX km2, it occurs at three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its lowland forest habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Near Threatened because although this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 22,214 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs at 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Honduras, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: It can be found in moist lowland forest, and premontane and lower montane wet forest. All specimens have been collected from broadleaf forests. It apparently depends on primary forest for survival and is likely not tolerant to habitat disturbance (McCranie and Castañeda 2007). The larvae apparently develop in streams. This species breeds in streams during long periods without rain (McCranie and Castañeda 2007).
threats:
A major threat to this species is the impact of landslides on upper clear water streams, as a result of strong storms and human activities taking place in the lower portions of the streams. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Encroaching subsistence agriculture and livestock grazing activities are threats to the buffer zone of Parque Nacional La Muralla (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

This species apparently has not yet been affected by Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis; according to Puschendorf et al. (2006), none of Incilius leucomyos were so far found to be infected. However, one dying individual was recorded with skin lesions in 2016 at 1,000 m asl in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). The potential effects of chytridiomycosis on this species remain unknown.
population: The population is apparently stable in appropriate habitat and the species is recorded on a regular basis. However, it appears to tolerate disturbance poorly, and is readily displaced by generalist species (Townsend et al. 2012). Thus, the population is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat.
range: Disjunct subpopulations of this species occur on the Atlantic slopes of north-central, in the departments of Colón, Atlantida, Olancho, Yoro and Comayagua in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). It occurs from sea level up to 1,600 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 22,214 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents 10 or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded in Parque Nacional La Muralla, Nombre de Dios, Pico Bonito, Cerro Azul Meambar, Sierra de Agalta, and Montaña de Botaderos, as well as, Jardín Botánico Lancetilla, and Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texiguat.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Research Needed
More studies are needed into this species' distribution, population status, and trends. Sampling for chytrid in this species is recommended, particularly in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,370 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than five threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species lives in lowland moist forest and premontane wet forest. It has been collected along shallow, slow-moving streams. It lays eggs in vegetation over streams and breeds by larval development.
threats:
In Montaña Macuzal, the habitat has been destroyed by large-scale cattle ranching, small-holder agriculture (crops), and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

In Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios, the major threat is habitat destruction from are large-scale cattle ranching, small-scale oil palm plantations in the lower elevations (0-100 m asl), small-scale cacao plantations, selective logging for valuable hardwoods followed by clear-cutting, human-induced fires, and the building of roads (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Cerro Correviento is unprotected forest, where the only forest that remains a patch of less than 1,500 hectares between 1,130-1,245 m asl, which is threatened by small-scale agriculture (crops), expanding human settlements, selective logging for valuable hardwoods followed by clear-cutting, landslides, human-induced fires and hunting trails and activities (L. Herrera and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). 

In Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, the area from which this species was recorded is subject to extensive landslides; these often severely impact the species habitat. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core part of the refuge (which currently is at 1,250 m asl) upslope, which would create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez and J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). There is also a proposal to shift the core parts both the Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Texiguat, which may create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez, J. Ramos Galdámez and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is also increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Chytridiomycosis is a threat to this species, and infected tadpoles have been found (M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It is a bigger threat to individuals occurring above 1,000 m asl (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).
population: It is commonly encountered and locally abundant (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs in Sierra de Nombre de Dios (Lancetilla Botanical Gardens, Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat, Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios and Cerro Correviento), as well as, forested streams outside of protected areas in this vicinity; and from historical records from 1940 for Montaña Macuzal, Atlantica, and Yoro departments, north-central Honduras, between 90-1,400 m asl (McCranie and Castañeda 2007). While its occurrence on Montaña Macuzal is included in the distribution map, it is coded as 'Presence Uncertain' and excluded from the extent of occurrence (EOO) calculation, as it is only known from historical records and there is uncertainty about whether it actually occurs there. It is not expected to be found much more widely than is already known, although it may occur in Parque Nacional Capiro y Calentura (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Its EOO is 4,370 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios, and Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat. In Nombre de Dios, park guard training is occurring which focuses specifically on amphibian surveying (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).  

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Research Needed
There is a need for close monitoring of the population status of this species, particularly given the threat of chytridiomycosis.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 336 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in north-central Honduras.
habitat: This species is found on the ground and on low vegetation along streams, in lower montane wet forest. It lays its eggs in patches of moss in trees and leaves overhanging streams; when the eggs hatch the tadpoles fall in to the stream. It probably breeds throughout the rainy season (Castañeda and McCranie 2011). It is known that species has male parental care of the egg mass and has demonstrated mechanical agitation behavior, however theft
threats:
McCranie and Wilson (2002) assigned this species a score of 15 on the Environmental Vulnerability Gauge, with a score of 16 representing the most vulnerable to population declines.

In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, mining activity to extract antimony at the type locality, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core part of the refuge (which currently is at 1,250 m asl) upslope, which would create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez and J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019).

As of 2016, a native boring pine beetle had devastated the pine forests of the region where this species occurs, which encourages widespread harvesting of the dying timber for energy production; increased intentional fires to eliminate the excess biomass; and subsequent conversion of burned areas to cropland. The destruction of the forests by the beetle had ceased as of 2019, but another outbreak will likely occur in the future during the next El Niño cycle (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: This species is uncommon within its very restricted range. For example, two individuals were recorded over five nights of surveys by two people at the type locality in 2004 (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Two individuals were heard calling in 2017 at the type locality in Refugio de Vida Silvestre <span class="il">Texiguat (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). In Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, it was locally common around streams in June 2012; for example, two males were recorded by two observers in one hour (Jocque and Argueta 2012).
range: This species is known from its type locality (Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat) and other localities in the Sierra Nombre de Dios between the Departamentos of Yoro and Atlantida, north-central Honduras (McCranie et al. 1993, Castañeda and McCranie 2011). There is also a recent photographic record of this species from Parque Nacional Pico Bonito (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019, Jocque and Argueta 2012). It occurs between 1,550-1,690 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 336 km2, which represents two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat and Parque Nacional Pico Bonito. 

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Research Needed
According to Castañeda and McCranie (2011), there is an urgently need for population monitoring of this species, as well as, additional natural history studies to understand the purpose and benefits of the mechanical agitation behavior of males.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 99 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in northern Honduras.
habitat: This stream-breeding species has been found along streams in primary premontane wet forest and humid low montane forest, but has also been found up to 500 m away from streams. It is unlikely to be tolerant of any form of anthropogenic habitat modification (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
threats:
Tadpoles have been found infected with the chytrid fungus in Quebrada de Oro, and this together with habitat loss is likely the cause of the historic population decline (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). The area from which this species was recorded in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito is subject to extensive landslides; these often severely impact the species habitat. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the reserve for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Harvesting of palm plants that this species uses may represent an additional threat (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2018). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core parts both the Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Texiguat, which may create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antuñez, J. Ramos Galdámez, J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population:
It is moderately infrequent and seems to be in decline (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). It was last documented at the type locality (Quebrada de Oro) in May 1996, when two metamorphs and two tadpoles were collected with deformed mouthparts (McCranie and Wilson 2002), which is often correlated with the chytrid infection in tadpoles of this genus (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). It is apparently extirpated from the type locality, but may still occur in unsurveyed parts of the surrounding areas (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). According to Townsend et al. (2011), the discovery of the species in Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat is the first evidence of its survival in 14 years. 

In September 2018, eight individuals were recorded in the Río Hilamito watershed; in December 2018, 30 individuals were recorded in a 400 m transect in the same watershed (J. Ramos Galdamez pers. comm. March 2019). In February 2019, 14 individuals were recorded in Río Mezapa watershed (J. Ramos Galdamez pers. comm. March 2019). These observations suggest that the species is more easily detectable during breeding periods (J. Ramos Galdamez pers. comm. March 2019). Due to habitat loss, the species is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was formerly only known from the type locality: Cerro Bufalo, Quebrado de Oro, Sierra Nombre de Dios, Departamento Atlantida in north-central Honduras, but it has disappeared from that site and is thus excluded from this species extent of occurrence (EOO). This species is now known from an additional site in Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat, within the Río Hilamito watershed (Townsend et al. 2011, L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019); and the adjacent Río Mezapa watershed (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs between 930-1,550 m asl. It may occur in the core zone of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and adjacent watersheds at suitable elevations, but likely does not occur much more widely (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 99 km2, and all individuals occur in a single threat-defined location in Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The only known localities are in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat. Intermittent amphibian population monitoring by several Honduran institutions is taking place in Texiguat (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

Conservation Needed
While the official designation of Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat and Parque Nacional Pico Bonito affords this species an official high level of protection, there is ongoing habitat loss within these areas. Therefore, improved enforcement and management of the two protected areas and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the protected areas of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Given the threat of chytridiomycosis, a captive-breeding programme might need to be established for this species.

Research Needed
Continued survey work is required in the core zone of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and adjacent watersheds at suitable elevations to determine if the species occurs in additional sites, and to monitor the population status and trends of this species in view of the severe risk of chytridiomycosis. Additional studies into this species' natural history are recommended.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,927 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: A stream-breeding species, it is typically found on vegetation along streams, and on boulders within streams, in Lowland Broadleaf Rainforest, Broadleaf Transitional Cloud Forest and Broadleaf Cloud Forest (Townsend 2014). It will not tolerate habitat disturbance, as it requires closed canopy and clear streams (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
threats:
In Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, the area from which this species was recorded is subject to extensive landslides which often severely impact the species' habitat. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core part of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, which may create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez, J. Ramos Galdámez and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). In Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios, the major threat is habitat destruction from large-scale cattle ranching, small-scale oil palm plantations in the lower elevations (0-100 m asl), small-scale cacao plantations, selective logging for valuable hardwoods followed by clear-cutting, human-induced fires, and the building of roads (L. Herrera and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). In Campiro y Calentura, deforestation is a major threat in the northern part caused by increasing urbanisation (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is also increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Cerro Correviento is unprotected forest, where the only forest that remains is a patch of less than 1,500 hectares between 1,130-1,245 m asl, which is threatened by small-scale agriculture (crops), expanding human settlements, selective logging for valuable hardwoods followed by clear-cutting, landslides, and human-induced fires (L. Herrera and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

Chytridiomycosis is very likely to be threat to this species (J. Kolby and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Other species have been found infected in the same localities as this species (Puschendorf et al. 2006), and tadpoles of this species have been observed with deformed mouthparts (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). Tadpoles of Ptychohyla hympotker found in Parque Nacional Cusuco that are infected with chytrid often exhibit severely deformed mouthparts, suggesting that the observed deformities within this species may be due to infection (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit at a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: It is relatively common, found regularly in surveys, and is locally abundant (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs in the Cordillera Nombre de Dios in the departments of Atlántida, Colón and Yoro in northern Honduras, between 160-1,580 m asl. <span id="docs-internal-guid-b69841f5-7fff-65eb-a8ba-838af5d9b26c">There is ongoing taxonomic work taking place on this species, which will affect the distribution of this species in the future (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,927 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is found in three protected areas, namely Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios, and Parque Nacional Capiro y Calentura.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Protection of habitat is also required at Cerro Correviento.

Research Needed
Further survey work is necessary to determine the degree to which chytrid poses a threat to this species. Further research is also required on population and the natural history of this species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Extinct. It was last seen in 1990, and exhaustive surveys at the species' known sites and the only other adjacent site with suitable habitat at suitable elevations have failed to record the species in several decades. The species experienced drastic population declines, probably due to chytridiomycosis and habitat loss, and has apparently not recuperated.
habitat: This species lived on the ground along mountain streams in premontane and lower montane moist forest. It presumably bred by direct development, with eggs laid on land, similar to other species in the Craugastor rugulosus series (McCranie and Castaneda 2007). It was not though to have tolerated habitat disturbance.
threats:
Species of the Craugastor rugulosus group appear to have undergone dramatic declines between mid 1980s to early 1990s across Honduras, including within undisturbed habitat which is a strong indicator of chytrid-related declines (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Chytridiomycosis is thought to have contributed to the extinction of this species (J. Townsend, L. Herrera and J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019), as well as habitat loss and degradation caused by agricultural encroachment, wood extraction, forest fires, water pollution, and landslides. The type locality of this species was already within a disturbed area of human settlement (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). The second locality, Rio Arcaqual, is affected at lower elevations by a small dam that is undergoing increased use pressure by local communities; and if the species was still present, then it is thought that this would be a threat to it (L. Herrera, J. Townsend and H. Vega pers. comm. March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population:
It had always been extremely rare, and is now considered to be extinct. Surveys were conducted for this species in 1995 and 1997, and no individuals were found (McCranie and Castaneda 2007). A two-night survey was conducted in 2008 at the type locality and did not record this species, and a 12 day survey (involving nine people for three days, and five people for the remaining six days) was conducted in 2015 that specifically looked for the two endemic amphibians on this mountain within suitable elevation range (including areas not previously surveyed for amphibians), and did not find the species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Mapance NGO have conducted monthly biodiversity surveys since 2015, surveying from the visitor centre up the mountain which includes the second site that this species is known from for which there have been no records (H. Vega pers. comm. March 2019).  

Furthermore, in 2017 and 2018 survey work was conducted in Volcan Pacayita, which is the only adjacent area with suitable habitat for the species; and no records of the species were found (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). The last verified sighting was in 1987 at the type locality, and in 1990 in Rio Arcaqual (Wilson and McCranie 2002). Given that there have been no records since 1990, despite extensive surveys in suitable habitat, it is likely that this species is extinct (J. Townsend, L. Herrera and J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).
range: This species was only known from two sites in the Montana de Celaque, Departments of Lempira and Ocotepeque, western Honduras, between 1,400-1,840 m asl. It was thought to be endemic to the mountain, and there is a lot of unsuitable habitat between the known locality and the next mountain (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) was 97 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: This species occurred in Parque Nacional Celaque.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population. However, since this species depends on forest cover and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of this habitat type throughout its range due to widespread forest loss, its population should be monitored.
habitat: The species lives on the forest floor in lowland moist forest and premontane wet forest. It requires forest cover, but is tolerant to some level of disturbance (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019), such as cocoa plantations and secondary forest. It has been observed as active during the daytime, which is unusual for species in this genus (McCranie and Castañeda 2007). It breeds by direct development.
threats:
The major threat to the species is habitat loss due to agricultural development for the cultivation of crops and livestock grazing, logging, development of infrastructure for human settlement, human-induced fires, and landslides. Deforestation and development for hydroelectric dams and palm oil plantations is another major threat (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Pollution resulting from agro-industry of cacao and palm oil is an additional concern for this species; the processing of coffee beans can result in a changing of the pH of rivers where this species occurs (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

The reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of cacao in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Other terrestrial Craugastor species living in the same habitats have been found infected by the chytrid fungus (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019); however, the degree of threat to this species remains unknown.
population: The species was formerly common, however now it is less common but is still regularly observed (Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). It is locally common in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs on the Atlantic versant from central Belize and central Guatemala to the vicinity of Correviento in Colón Department on the northern coast of Honduras, from 20–1,180 m asl (Honduras Red List Workshop March 2019).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is found in several protected areas in all three countries.

Conservation Needed
Despite the existence of protected areas, agricultural and land development is a continued threat for the species. Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest in Honduras (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) because this species has not recuperated from a drastic historical population decline, inferred from the apparent disappearance or near-disappearance of the population, possibly due to chytridiomycosis. Should a population of this species exist, then it is reasonable to assume that is very small, probably containing fewer than 50 mature individuals. Furthermore, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 17 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from a single threat-defined location, and the population is threatened by ongoing habitat loss due to landslides, agricultural and livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires. It is tagged as Possibly Extinct because, while it has not been seen in its known locality, there is a possibility that it exists in the core zone of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, which requires further survey effort.
habitat: The two known type specimens were collected along a very small stream in lower montane wet forest. Reproduction likely occurs via direct development.
threats:
While certain parts of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, the area from which this species was recorded is subject to extensive landslides; these often severely result in significant modification of the streams and streamside environment. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Additionally, it is noteworthy to mention that by 1996 that most, if not all, streamside Craugastor species known to occur above 900 m asl were thought to have disappeared in Honduras, even in pristine habitats (Wilson and McCranie 1998). Reasons for the disappearances of this species remains unclear, although infection with chytridiomycosis together with the alteration of its habitat due to extensive landslides is a strong possibility (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population:
This species is only known from two specimens collected in 1980. A landslide occurred in 1988 which destroyed the stream where the two known type specimens were collected. The area was extensively sampled prior to the landslide through the 1980s, but still only two specimens were ever recorded. Between 1980 and 2005, surveys to the area at least 10 times did not turn up any additional specimens (McCranie and Castaneda 2007). Surveys to lower elevations in 2008-2009 also did not record the species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

There is a possibility that this species is already extinct (McCranie et al. 2018); however, additional surveys are needed in areas of the core zone of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito to confirm whether the species is still extant (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). If a population of this species exists, then it is reasonable to assume that is very small and decreasing, and would probably contain fewer than 50 mature individuals.
range: This species is known only from the type locality, Cerro Bufalo in Cordillera Nombre de Dios on the Atlantic slope south of La Ceiba in northern Honduras at 1,520 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 17 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The type locality of this species is within Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, however legal protection of the land is limited (J.R. McCranie pers. comm.). As a result of the AZE-CEPF project in 2008, six para-biologist training workshops took place in Pico Bonito in 2009 (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The option of a captive-breeding programme might also need to be explored for this species should a subpopulation be detected in the wild (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

Research Needed
Surveys are needed to determine whether or not there is a surviving population (J. Townsend, L. Herrera and J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 491 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the the Río Choluteca watershed, Honduras.
habitat: The preferred habitat of this species is premontane and lower montane moist forest and the edge of premontane dry forest (McCranie and Castañeda 2007). Some specimens have been recorded near Tegucigalpa (probably when the species recently described), but the species has not been recorded recently in the urban area. It is tolerant of moderate levels of habitat alteration as it has been recorded in secondary habitats (C. Antúnez and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in leaf-litter and under rocks, and has been collected along streams and in a citrus grove away from streams. Reproduction occurs by direct development.
threats:
This species occurs in two of the best managed protected areas in the country (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Nonetheless, the reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Outside of protected areas, major threats to the species include agricultural encroachment, wood extraction, forest fires, urban development, water pollution, and landslides (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

As of 2016, a native boring pine beetle has devastated the pine forests of the region where this species occurs, which encourages widespread harvesting of the dying timber for energy production; increased intentional fires to eliminate the excess biomass; and subsequent conversion of burned areas to cropland. The destruction of the forests by the beetle have ceased as of 2019, however another outbreak will likely occur in the future during the next El Niño cycle (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010). Several other species in the genus in Honduras have experienced drastic declines due to disease, such as chytridiomycosis, so the population should be monitored (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: Until 2010, there were no sightings of this species since 1985, despite one targeted effort to search for this species. In 2010, this species was rediscovered at Los Golondrinas, Francisco Morazán, in Parque Nacional La Tigra, where about 12 specimens were observed (McCranie et al. 2010). In October 2015, six individuals were recorded in two nights of surveys by three people in Parque Nacional La Tigra and its surroundings (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). In 2016, two individuals were recorded near a stream in Golondrinas (C. Antúnez pers. comm. March 2019). This species remains uncommon, though it is easier to find after heavy rains (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the Río Choluteca watershed from Cerro La Tigra and Cerro Uyuca to El Zamorano in south-central Honduras, at elevations between 800-2,000 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 491 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents approximately three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is known to occur in the Parque Nacional La Tigra and the Reserva Biológica Cerro Uyuca, which are both well-managed and well-protected (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is recommended to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Research Needed
Additional survey work in the dry forest is recommended to determine the status of this species in that habitat type (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) because this species has not recuperated from a drastic historical population decline, inferred from the apparent disappearance or near-disappearance of the population, possibly due to chytridiomycosis. Should a population of this species exist, then it is reasonable to assume that is very small, probably containing fewer than 50 mature individuals, and is threatened by ongoing habitat loss.
habitat: It occurs and breeds (by direct development) in leaf-litter on the ground in lowland and premontane moist forest. It is often found near streams in primary and moderately disturbed forests, and individuals have been encountered on the forest floor or on stones along streams (McCranie and Castañeda 2007).
threats:
By 1996 that most, if not all, streamside Craugastor species known to occur above 900 m asl were thought to have disappeared in Honduras, even in pristine habitats (Wilson and McCranie 1998). Since the observed species decline has taken place in suitable habitat this is suggestive that chytridiomycosis was the cause (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

The main threats to the species' habitat are forest fires, especially during extended dry seasons. The cloud forest is being destroyed and fragmented by subsistence agricultural use and coffee plantations. As of 2016, a native boring pine beetle has devastated the pine forests of the region where this species occurs, which encourages widespread harvesting of the dying timber for energy production; increased intentional fires to eliminate the excess biomass; and subsequent conversion of burned areas to cropland. The destruction of the forests by the beetle have ceased as of 2019, however another outbreak will likely occur in the future during the next El Niño cycle (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Although this species occurs in the Río Plátano Biosphere Reserve, forest destruction throughout this species' range, mainly as a result of agricultural expansion and extensive cattle ranching mainly fuelled by drug trafficking and illegal selective logging for hardwoods, is nonetheless rampant and causing a decrease in available habitat for this species (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population:
Formerly, this species was relatively common along streams in Sierra de Agalta in the 1980s (McCranie and Wilson 2002), but apparently experienced drastic population declines possibly due to a combination of chytridiomycosis and habitat loss. Substantial habitat has been lost in the past couple of decades. Two nights of surveys in 1997 and 1998 along a stream in Sierra de Agalta failed to produce this species (McCranie and Wilson 2002). In 1999, only a single individual was recorded at Quebrada Machín (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). In 2006, extensive surveys were conducted in Sierra de Agalta, but no specimens were found (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Intensive surveys in Río Catacamas, Sierra de Agalta in 2015 did not turn up any individuals (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). This species has apparently disappeared from known localities in Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta (McCranie and Castañeda 2007).

Short surveys at known localities in Río Platano did not record the species in 2018 (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). The status of the population at other known sites remains unknown and require intensive survey effort to determine whether the species has disappeared there as well (F. Castañeda and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). If a population of this species exists, then it is reasonable to assume that is very small and decreasing, and would probably contain fewer than 50 mature individuals.
range: This species is known from the Sierra de Agalta, Olancho, northeastward to the Montaña de las Marías, Olancho, and tributaries of Ríos Paulaya and Plátano, Colón, on the Atlantic versant of east-central and northeastern Honduras. It is known from elevations of 150-1,460 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It has been collected within the Reserve de la Biosfera Río Platano and on the edge of Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta.

Conservation Needed
Because ex situ conservation management might be needed if more specimens are found, it is suggested that an analog species, such as Craguastor aurilegalus or C. laevissimus, is brought into captivity to develop husbandry and breeding protocols that can be used as a template for this species.

Research Needed
Further survey work of known localities of this species is required to determine the population status of this species and the reasons for its decline within pristine habitats (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since XXXX, and extensive searches in the appropriate habitat, during the appropriate season within the known range, have failed to locate this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Extinct because it has not been recorded since 1974, and extensive searches in the appropriate habitat, during the appropriate season within the known range, have failed to locate this species in several decades. The species experienced drastic population declines, probably due to habitat loss or a combination of habitat loss and chytridiomycosis, and has apparently not recuperated.
habitat: The species stream-associated species occurred in the Premontane Wet Forest formation. It reproduced by direct development along streams.
threats: Habitat loss due to urbanisation and coffee farming is taking place in the region where this species was previously extant, which may have played a role in the the dramatic population decline. Some other species of Craugastor that are associated with streams have undergone dramatic declines and disappearances at higher elevations, possibly due to chytridiomycosis, which probably contributed to the extinction of this species (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population:
It is known from 24 specimens. Formerly, it was moderately common, but has experienced a precipitous decline. It was last observed in 1974 by J. Lynch. A visit to the area of the type locality in 27 July 1996 failed to turn up individuals of this or any other amphibian and the area at that time was considerably more deforested than it was during 1974 (McCranie and Wilson 2002). Apparently the small stream where Lynch collected the type series had presumably long since dried up as a result of the continued deforestation of the steep montane slopes in the vicinity of the type locality (McCranie and Wilson 2002). There have been many efforts to locate this species since its apparent disappearance. For example, surveys between 2016-2018 have been conducted at the vicinity of the type locality at least 10 times and did not recorded the species, but recorded other species of Craugastor (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019).

In addition to the habitat devastation having taken place in the vicinity of its type locality, the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis was reported in some frogs at a higher elevation site (1,690 m asl) from the Sierra de Omoa in northwestern Honduras by Kolby et al. (2010). Given that there have been no records since 1974, despite extensive surveys in suitable habitat, it is likely that this species is extinct (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
range: This species was formerly known from moderate elevations in the Sierra de Omoa, near San Pedro Sula, on the slope of the Atlantic in Cortés, Honduras, between 760-1,150 m asl (McCranie and Castañeda 2007).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It was not known to occur in any protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 6,961 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its forest habitat throughout its range.
habitat: This species lives on the forest floor in premontane and montane wet forest. It requires forest cover, but is tolerant to some levels of disturbance, such as coffee plantations. It presumably breeds by direct development.
threats:
The major threat to this species is severe habitat loss due to agricultural development, livestock grazing, logging, human settlement, and increased frequency of fires (Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). 

In Honduras, the reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The cultivation of cardamom, coffee, and flowers is taking place within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cusuco (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019), and associated pollution from herbicide and pesticide use, and water pollution from coffee harvesting processes [aguas mieles] (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Another major threat is an increase in intentional human-induced fires for clearing of habitat for agriculture (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). The building of roads in view of increasing hydroelectric development, increasing human settlements, and selective logging are causing habitat loss within the park (J. Kolby, F. Castañeda, M. Solís and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The trampling of leaf-litter, erosion of trails, and physical disturbance caused by high numbers of people through tourism activities and international research groups is an additional issue (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). In Reserva de Merendón, associated pollution from the use of herbicides and pesticides and coffee harvesting processes, and human-induced forest fires are threats to this species (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The habitat at Quebrada Grande, Department of Copan is being lost and fragmented for coffee plantations and cattle ranching, and the habitat has been almost completely destroyed due to these activities (F. Castañeda and M. Solis pers. comm. March 2019). 

In addition, chytrid infection has been detected in this species (4.9% prevalence; Kolby et al. 2010). It continues to be recorded with low to moderate prevalence of chytrid infection; one dying adult was found with severe infection and likely chytridiomycosis (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019), thus the disease is considered to be a threat to the species.

Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019).
