Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: This is a moderately common species in Guatemala (M. Acevedo pers. comm. August 2019). In Honduras, it is considered to be locally abundant (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019), and it is regularly recorded in surveys in its known localities (J. Townsend, J. Kolby and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range:
This species was previously known from extreme eastern Guatemala near the Honduran border, and from the following localities in western and north-central Honduras: Cerro Quebrada Grande, Montaña Pico Pijol, Montaña La Fortuna, Montaña Portillo Grande, Parque Nacional Cusuco, and Montaña Merendón west of San Pedro Sula, between 1,050-1,800 m asl.

However, following morphological analysis, subpopulations from Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texíguat in the Cordillera Nombre de Dios in Yoro and Atlantida Departments; from the eastern slopes of Montaña Pico Pijol; and to the east on Montaña Macuzal near Portillo Grande, and Montaña de Mataderos in Yoro Department, all in Honduras, have now been assigned to Craugastor gutschei (McCranie 2018). This species is now restricted to extreme eastern Guatemala and northwestern Honduras in Parque Nacional Cusuco, Cerro Azul de Copan and Reserva de Merendón, between 600-1,500 m asl (McCranie 2018, L. Herrera, J. Townsend and J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). It is also known from a single locality, Quebrada las Cuevas, in Santa Barbara Department (McCranie 2015), and from Monte de la Virgen on the northern slope of Montaña de Celaque from Parque Nacional Montaña de Celaque (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It is possible that it may be found between known localities in Honduras (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 6,961 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Cusuco, Parque Nacional Cerro Azul de Copan and Reserva de Merendón in Honduras. In Guatemala, it occurs in Reserva Protector Manantiales Sierra Caral and Parque Nacional Muncipal La Uníon Zacapa (Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019).

Conservation Needed 
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Ex-situ captive breeding is also recommended for this species (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Further taxonomic research is required for the Craugastor rostralis group to evaluate taxonomic relationships between species in the group (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Population surveys and research on natural history and ecology would also be useful (L. Herrera and J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) because this species has not recuperated from a drastic historical population decline, inferred from the apparent disappearance or near-disappearance of the population, possibly due to a combination of disease and habitat loss. Should a population of this species exist, then it is reasonable to assume that is very small, probably containing fewer than 50 mature individuals, and is threatened by ongoing habitat loss. It is tagged as Possibly Extinct because, while it has not been observed in historical sites despite exhaustive surveys, specimens potentially belonging to this species have been recorded in a new locality (Correviento); in addition, there is a possibility that it still exists in remote areas of Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat, which requires further survey effort.
habitat: It occurs in leaf-litter in lower montane wet forest. It is likely not tolerant of habitat disturbance (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Breeding takes place by direct development.
threats:
The area from which this species was recorded is subject to extensive landslides; these often severely impact the species habitat. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core parts both the Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Texiguat, which may create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez, J. Ramos Galdámez, and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

Cerro Correviento is unprotected forest, where the only forest that remains is a patch (<1,500 ha) between 1,130-1,245 m asl, which is threatened by small-scale agriculture (crops), expanding human settlements, selective logging for valuable hardwoods followed by clear-cutting, landslides, and human-induced fires (L. Herrera and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010). Several other species in the genus in Honduras have experienced drastic declines due to disease (such as chytridiomycosis), although it would be surprising for this to be the case in this species since it is not associated with streams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: This species has always been rare and difficult to find; it is only known from a handful of specimens. Visits to Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat in 1995, 1996, 2003–2005, 2016, and 2017, failed to turn up any additional individuals (McCranie and Castañeda 2007, F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). In 2013, six individuals possibly belonging to this species were recorded (1 male and 1 female collected) by four people over three nights in Correviento (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019), but the identification of these specimens are still in question (J. Townsend pers. comm. April 2019). There is a possibility that this species is extinct; however, further field surveys are required to verify this (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). If a population of this species exists, then it is reasonable to assume that is very small and decreasing, and would probably contain fewer than 50 mature individuals.
range: This species was historically known from two areas in the west and central portion of the Cordillera Nombre de Dios (CND) in northern Honduras (McCranie and Castañeda 2007). Two specimens collected from Correviento, Colón Department in 2013 may belong to this species, but additional material is needed to confirm the true identity of these specimens (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). It is known from elevations between 1,550-1,800 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is known from Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and in Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat. 

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The option of a captive-breeding programme might need to be explored for this species should a subpopulation be detected in the wild.

Research Needed
Further survey work is required to determine where this species is still surviving and to establish its population status. Genetic and morphological comparison of specimens from Correviento and the specimens from Cordillera Nombre de Dios is needed to verify their identity (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered given that the species experienced a drastic population decline in the 1990s, possibly due to chytridiomycosis. While the species was observed as recently at 2010, and is probably still surviving, it can no longer be found in most of its historical range and it is suspected that the population consists of fewer than 50 mature individuals.
habitat: It occurs and reproduces by direct development on the ground close to streams in premontane and lower montane wet forest. It is probably not tolerant to anthropogenic habitat alteration (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).
threats:
The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). As of 2016, a native boring pine beetle has devastated the pine forests of the region where this species occurs, which encourages widespread harvesting of the dying timber for energy production; increased intentional fires to eliminate the excess biomass; and subsequent conversion of burned areas to cropland. The destruction of the forests by the beetle have ceased as of 2019, however another outbreak will likely occur in the future during the next El Niño cycle (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

In Parque Nacional La Muralla, encroaching subsistence agriculture and livestock grazing activities are threats to the buffer zone of the national park (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In Parque Nacional Pico Pijol, major threats to this species include extensive habitat loss for coffee plantations, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, the creation of roads for coffee plantations and logging, and the subsequent erosion and pollution caused by coffee farming and logging. As mentioned, due to the reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI), that has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Although habitat destruction is a major threat, the species' past decline in pristine areas is not entirely understood. However, it should be noted that many other species of Craugastor that are associated with streams have undergone dramatic declines and disappearances at higher elevations due to chytridiomycosis, and so this is presumably a major threat to this species (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: Although formerly relatively common, this species experienced a precipitous decline sometime in the 1990s (McCranie 2010, McCranie 2018), possibly due to chytridiomycosis or a combination of disease and habitat loss. Until 2010, there had been no records of this species since 1993; however, it was rediscovered in a stream in Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texíguat in April 2010, where two individuals were observed; however, despite ca. two more hours of night searches along the stream, no other Craugastor were seen (McCranie et al. 2010). Surveys at Texíguat (2016-2018), Parque Nacional Pico Pijol (2016-2018) and La Muralla (2018) failed to record any individuals, although these were not targeted surveys for this particular species (F. Castañeda, J.M Solis, J. Townsend, and J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). It is too early to know if this species is recovering from near extinction or is still in a period of decline (McCranie et al. 2010); however, it is likely that it survives in low numbers, possibly fewer than 50 mature individuals, and due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
range: This species is known from three localities in north-central Honduras: Parque Nacional La Muralla, in north-western Olancho Department; Montaña La Fortuna, in Parque Nacional Pico Pijol, near Portillo Grande in Yoro Department; and Cerro San Francisco, in Atlantida Department. It has been recorded at 1,125-1,900 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional La Muralla, Parque Nacional Pico Pijol and Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat.

Conservation Needed
Because ex situ conservation management might be needed if more specimens are found, it is suggested that an analogue species, such as Craguastor aurilegalus or C. laevissimus, is brought into captivity to develop husbandry and breeding protocols that can be used as a template for this species (J. Kolby, F. Castañeda and L. Carrillo pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Further survey work of known localities of this species is required to determine the population status of this species and the reasons for its decline within pristine habitats.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence is 24 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals occur in a single location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on the Cerro Cantagallo and nearby mountains in Honduras.
habitat: It is arboreal, living in bromeliads in a several small patches of cloud forest surrounded by agriculture. It has so far only been recorded from primary forest and the forest edge (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). It presumably breeds by direct development and is not dependent upon water.
threats:
The major threat to the species is clearance of its remaining forest habitat for subsistence farming, the collection of bromeliads and moss on which this species depends for survival, as well as human-induced fires during the dry seasons, and the construction of roads (F. Castañeda, J.M. Solis, and C. Antúnez pers. comm. March 2019). Some suitable habitat was still available in November 2018, but the amount of habitat has been reduced since the 2008 conservation assessment (J.M. Solís and F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: The forest in the area where this species occurs is highly fragmented, although the species is locally common in good patches of forest (F. Castañeda pers. obs. 2018). The species was recorded at the type locality in 2007 (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). In 2018, three individuals were recorded over six person-hours ca 4 km SW of the type locality (J.M. Solís and F. Castañeda pers. comm. 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is only known from the type locality of Cerro Cantagallo and some nearby mountains in the municipality of Lepaterique, Honduras, between 1,840-2,070 m asl. There is other suitable habitat nearby, and so it is likely to occur in additional sites at appropriate elevations in the vicinity of the type locality (F. Castañeda and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 24 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals are considered to occur in one threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species occurs in Reserva Biologica Yerba Buena (McCranie and Wilson 2002; ICF database), but this is not managed for biodiversity conservation, and the habitat is subject to disturbance and fragmentation (F. Castañeda and J.M Solís pers. comm. March 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved management and protection of this area is urgently needed. Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
More studies are needed into this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 9,349 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in western Honduras and Guatemala.
habitat: This species is found in arboreal bromeliads and on the ground in lower montane wet forest. It is thought to tolerate moderate levels of habitat disturbance, such as naturally shaded coffee plantations and forest edge (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019). It breeds by direct development and lays eggs in soil on the ground (Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019).
threats:
The major threats to this species include deforestation for extensive small-scale agriculture, including crops, coffee plantations and livestock, large and small-scale logging activities, and human-induced fires, even within the core zones of protected areas (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019).

In Honduras, the reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The cultivation of cardamom, coffee, and flowers is taking place within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cusuco and Reserva de Merendón (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The building of roads in view of increasing hydroelectric development, human settlements, and selective logging are causing habitat loss within Parque Nacional Cusuco (J. Kolby, F. Castañeda, J.M. Solís, L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in extreme weather events are being observed throughout this species' range, including an increase in hurricanes and droughts (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019).

In Guatemala, a specimen of this species has been recorded infected with the chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis. Chytrid (Bd) infection has also been detected in this species in Honduras (J. Kolby pers. comm. 2008). The severity of this threat to the species has not yet been evaluated; it is confirmed to be susceptible to infection, but it is unknown whether the species develops chytridiomycosis (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of this fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Mesoamerica (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019).
population: In Honduras, it is locally common; however, it may be declining in Parque Nacional Cerro Azul and Parque Nacional Cusuco due to habitat loss (F. Castañeda pers. comm. 2007, 2019; J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). In Guatemala, it appears to be locally common at its known sites (C. Vásquez-Almazán and S. Rovito pers. comm. 2019). It is restricted to remnant forest habitat throughout its range, and there is a lack of habitat connectivity between known sites attributed to the inhospitable nature of the surrounding agricultural matrix; therefore, it is assumed that the population is severely fragmented (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
range: This species is known from Honduras and Guatemala. In Honduras, it is found in a few small isolated areas in the west of Honduras: El Chaguitón and El Portillo (Reserva Biológica Güisayote), department of Ocotepeque; Quebrada Grande in Parque Nacional Cerro Azul, department of Copán; and Parque Nacional Cerro Cusuco and Reserva de Merendón, department of Cortés (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In Guatemala, it is found in the area of La Unión and Zacapa, Department of Zacapa, and in the mountains above the city of Zacapa. Additional records have been reported from Morales and Los Amates in the Department of Izabal, Guatemala (S. Rovito pers. comm. August 2019). It is unlikely to occur any more widely in Guatemala (Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). Records from the Sierra de Metapán in Santa Ana Department, north-west El Salvador, refer to Bolitoglossa heiroreias (Greenbaum 2004). It ranges from 1,370–2,000 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,349 km2 and all individuals are considered to occur in ten or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Honduras, the species occurs within protected areas, namely Parque Nacional Cusuco and Reserva de Merendón; Parque Nacional Cerro Azul, and Reserva Biológica Güisayote. In Güisayote, an NGO, Asociación Ecológica de San Marcos de Ocotepeque, manages the reserve and is currently buying land for habitat restoration (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). There is also a visitor centre which has park guards that conduct monitoring and educational environmental awareness (L. Herrera and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Parque Nacional Cusuco is one of the few areas of Honduras that has regular patrolling by park rangers supported by Panthera and Operation Wallacea; the rangers patrol the southern portion of the park and effectively report any illegal activities (F. Castaneda pers. comm. March 2019). Operation Wallacea has been conducting annual biodiversity monitoring in Parque Nacional El Cusuco since 2005 (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). UNAH-VS and the environmental division of San Pedro Sula municipality are conducting biodiversity monitoring of Merendón water production forest and building capacity in the area, and has plans to extend this to Parque Nacional El Cusuco (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The municipality of San Pedro Sula has an active ranger team protecting the watersheds and fighting forest fires in the Merendón water production forest and the southern portion of Parque Nacional El Cusuco (L. Herrera and F. Castaneda pers. comm. March 2019). In Guatemala, it occurs in Parque Regional Municipal La Uníon and Reserva Protector de Manantiales Sierra Caral (C. Vásquez-Almazán pers. comm. August 2019). A captive breeding programme for this species was established in Toledo Zoo; however, this programme is no longer active (C. Vásquez-Almazán pers. comm. August 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Mesoamerica and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Additional surveys are needed throughout its known range to better understand its population status (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 68 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Parque Nacional La Muralla, Honduras.
habitat: This species is found on low vegetation, tree ferns, on the ground, and on arboreal bromeliads in lower montane wet forest. It is unlikely to be tolerant of any form of anthropogenic habitat degradation (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It breeds by direct development and is not dependent upon water for reproduction.
threats:
Encroaching subsistence agriculture and livestock grazing activities are threats to the buffer zone of  Parque Nacional La Muralla (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of this fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is a naturally uncommon species within its restricted range (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It is infrequently encountered; this lack of records is probably, at least in part, due to the difficulty of detecting this species in its natural habitat (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It was observed as recently as 2018, where a single individual was recorded during the rainy season (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from Monte Escondido in Parque Nacional La Muralla on the Atlantic versant in the north-western portion of the Department of Olancho, north-central Honduras, at 1,430-1,550 m asl. It is likely to be endemic to the vicinity of the type locality (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 68 km<sup>2</sup> and all individuals are considered to occur in one threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The only known site is in Parque Nacional La Muralla, which was declared as a protected area in 1987, but this area is poorly protected, and habitat loss is continuing.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). 

Research Needed
Additional research is needed on this species' distribution, population status and trends. Another avenue for future research includes natural history studies.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 137 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on the Sierra de Omoa in Honduras.
habitat: This nocturnal species has been found on low to mid vegetation (up to 2 m above the ground), on bromeliads, and on the ground of lower montane cloud forest. It breeds by direct development and is not dependent upon water. It is unlikely to be tolerant of anthropogenic habitat disturbance (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). This species has extreme sexual dimorphism (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
threats:
The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The cultivation of cardamom, coffee, and flowers is taking place within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cusuco (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another major threat is an increase in intentional human-induced fires for clearing of habitat for agriculture (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). The building of roads in view of increasing hydroelectric development, increasing human settlements, and selective logging are causing habitat loss within the park (J. Kolby, F. Castañeda, J.M. Solís, L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Local people harvest 'hearts of palm' from the palm tree species used by this salamander, which represents an additional threat (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The trampling of leaf-litter, erosion of trails, and physical disturbance caused by high numbers of people through tourism activities and international research groups is an additional issue (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Anecdotal evidence suggests that the climate in the area where this species occurs has become much drier and warmer in the last three decades, which represents a major concern for this cloud forest species (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

Chytrid (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis) infection was reported in this species in 2008 (J. Kolby pers. comm. 2008). There has been no further work on the specific effects of this disease on this species since then; however, there is no indication that is a major threat to the species at present (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of this fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It was formerly believed to be an uncommon species based on the species' description (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). However, in recent years, this species has been found more commonly than previously thought thanks to additional survey efforts. It is now considered to be locally common (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). For example, ca 20 individuals were recorded in a single night of surveys at El Danto and El Quetzal in Cusuco National Park (J.M. Solís pers. obs. 2009). The population is suspected to be declining due to ongoing habitat loss (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
range: This species is known only from the Sierra de Omoa on the Atlantic versant of north-western Honduras at 1,300-2,200 m asl. It is almost certainly endemic to the Sierra de Omoa (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The habitat in lower elevation areas is highly fragmented due to urbanisation and agriculture, but it is possible that there is still connectivity between subpopulations (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Its extent of occurrence is 137 km<sup>2</sup>,<sup> </sup>which represents one threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional El Cusuco and Reserva de Merendón. Parque Nacional El Cusuco is one of the few areas of Honduras that has regular patrolling by park rangers supported by Panthera and Operation Wallacea; the rangers patrol the southern portion of the park and effectively report any illegal activities (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Operation Wallacea has been conducting annual biodiversity monitoring in Parque Nacional El Cusuco since 2005 (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). UNAH-VS and the environmental division of San Pedro Sula municipality are conducting biodiversity monitoring of Merendón water production forest and building capacity in the area, and has plans to extend this to Parque Nacional El Cusuco (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The municipality of San Pedro Sula has an active ranger team protecting the watersheds and fighting forest fires in the Merendón water production forest and the southern portion of Parque Nacional El Cusuco (L. Herrera and F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

Conservation Needed
While the protection of the south-eastern portion of Parque Nacional El Cusuco has been improved in recent years, there is still a need for additional protection and enforcement of the remaining habitat in the area (e.g., north-western portion; (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Further survey work is needed to determine the current population status of this species, as well as the possible impacts of chytrid fungi. Another avenue for future research includes natural history studies.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 92 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Sierra de Agalta of Honduras.
habitat: This species lives in lower montane primary wet forest (cloud and elfin forest) where it can be found in bromeliads near the ground, on low moss-covered branches of trees, and on the ground under moss and leaves. It is not expected to be tolerant of any form of anthropogenic habitat disturbance (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). It breeds by direct development.
threats:
The main threats to the species are forest fires, especially during extended dry seasons. Fires are most often in the surrounding cloud forest, but still represent a threat to the species if and when they spread. The elfin forest is still intact, but the surrounding cloud forest is being destroyed and fragmented by subsistence agricultural use and coffee plantations. As of 2016, a native boring pine beetle has devastated the pine forests of the region where this species occurs, which encourages widespread harvesting of the dying timber for energy production; increased intentional fires to eliminate the excess biomass; and subsequent conversion of burned areas to cropland. The destruction of the forests by the beetle had ceased as of 2019, but another outbreak will likely occur in the future during the next El Niño cycle (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is a locally common species in the elfin forest, but is uncommon in cloud forest (F. Castañeda pers. comm. 2007, 2019). It has been recorded as recently as 2011 (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known only from the Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta, in the Departamento de Olancho, east-central Honduras, between 1,840-2,240 m asl. It may be present in nearby elfin and cloud forest within the same mountain range, but this requires confirmation. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 92 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement of the national park and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Better management particularly to control frequent fires is required. Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). 

Research Needed
Additional studies are needed into the ecology of this species' and its association with its extremely unique elfin forest habitat in Sierra de Agalta (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,235 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species lives in arboreal bromeliads, on low vegetation, and on the ground under rotten plant material, in Broadleaf Cloud Forest (Townsend 2014). It is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Breeding takes place by direct development.
threats:
Major threats to this species include extensive habitat loss for coffee plantations, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, the creation of roads for coffee plantations and logging, and the subsequent erosion and pollution caused by coffee farming and logging. The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

In Montaña Macuzal, the habitat has been destroyed by large-scale cattle ranching, small-holder agriculture (crops), and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is considered to be a fairly common species, which is locally abundant (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs in the Montana de Pijol (in Yoro Department), Quebrada de Oro, Cerro Bufalo, and Cerro San Francisco (Atlántida Department), all in north-central Honduras, between 980-1,920 m asl. There is ongoing taxonomic work taking place on this species, which will affect the distribution of this species in the future (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,235 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Pico Pijol.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is urgently needed in Montaña Macuzal (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). It is currently unprotected, with less than 2 km2 of forest is remaining, and the current status of that forest is unknown (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta is managed by two regional ICF offices that are relatively well positioned for park management; additional resources should be directed to these offices to increase their effectiveness (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Proactive, precautionary steps should also be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Further research is required on population and ecology (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 99 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat throughout its restricted range in Honduras and El Salvador.
habitat: This species lives on low vegetation in lower montane moist forest, and in nearby degraded areas where there is good vegetation cover. It is unlikely to tolerate habitat disturbance, and requires forest cover (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Animals have been recorded from bromeliads, a tree fern, on tree trunks, under ground cover, and close to streams in cloud forest (Köhler et al. 2006). It breeds by direct development.
threats:
The major threat to this species is habitat loss and degradation due to the impacts of human-induced forest fires and encroachment by subsistence and small-scale farming. In addition, a road passing through Reserva Biológica Güisayote is allowing for increased traffic passing through the area (L. Herrera and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Herbicides and pesticides are additional threats to this species and its habitat (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). In El Salvador, this species occurs on private land and is not legally protected, and satellite images between 2010–2019 show changes in the use of land for agricultural activities (V. Henríquez, F.S. Álvarez, and E. Morán pers. comm. June 2019). There is also uncontrolled tourism in the Cerro El Pital area which affects the species, as tourists collect any plant material they can find for firewood, destroying practically all the microhabitat of the species (V. Henríquez pers. comm. June 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat as it is expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates for the species. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed in parts of its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (e.g. droughts) (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019).
population: It is an uncommon species. Surveys were conducted in 2008 on the Honduran side of Cerro El Pital, which recorded two individuals (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It is only known from a single individual from Reserva Biológica Güisayote, despite multiple visits to the site (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The species is locally rare in the Cerro El Pital area in El Salvador (V. Henríquez, F.S. Álvarez, and E. Morán pers. comm. June 2019), where only 4 individuals were recorded during a survey in March 2010 and no individuals were found in a return visit in April 2010 (Henríquez 2010, V. Henríquez pers. comm. June 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs on Cerro El Pital in the Department of Ocotepeque in south-west Honduras and in adjacent north-western El Salvador, between 2,150-2,700 m asl. In 2017, it was recorded in Reserva Biológica Güisayote in Honduras, extending its range slightly to the northeast (J. Townsend and L. Herrera unpubl. data March 2019). It is unlikely to be found between known localities as there is no suitable habitat available; and it is not thought to occur more widely, however it may be found throughout Reserva Biológica Güisayote (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 99 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Reserva Biológica Cerro El Pital, and this was declared as a biological reserve on the Honduran side in 1987. It is also known from Reserva Biológica Güisayote (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). In Güisayote, Asociación Ecológica de San Marcos de Ocotepeque (AESMO) NGO manage the reserve, and are currently buying land for habitat restoration (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). There is also a visitor centre which has park guards that conduct monitoring and conduct educational environmental awareness (L. Herrera and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). In El Salvador, this species is in a private protected area, but high tourist traffic and expanding agriculture is placing a high degree of pressure on the habitat (V. Henríquez, F.S. Álvarez, and E. Morán pers. comm. June 2019). There are no protection initiatives in El Salvador for this species.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of the protected area to include all of the Cerro El Pital is urgently needed. Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and El Salvador and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

Research Needed
Habitat surveys are required on the Honduran side of Cerro El Pital to assess the state of the habitat (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Research is also required on the natural history of this species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019), as well as, threats to the population.

habitat: It lives in lower montane wet forest and montane rainforest and is found in arboreal, and sometimes terrestrial, bromeliads. It has only been found in good quality forest with high humidity and is unlikely to be tolerant of habitat disturbance or opening up of the forest (Honduras Red List Assessment March 2019). Breeding takes place by direct development.
threats:
The forest habitat in Parque Nacional Montaña de Santa Bárbara is being deforested for coffee and avocado, fruits, and flowers (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). A lack of capacity to manage the national park is an additional concern (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition, selective logging for timber and forest fires are affecting its habitat the park (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Surveys in 2008 in the highest areas of Parque Nacional Montaña de Santa Bárbara found that there are large areas of suitable habitat without roads or people, and logging operations or significant expansion of agriculture into these areas of the park is considered unlikely because of the steep topography (T. Papenfuss and S. Rovito pers. comm. 2008). However, extended dry seasons have resulted in increased rates of forest fires spreading even to the higher areas of the park (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010). 

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It can be locally abundant in suitable habitat and where bromeliads are present. Surveys in 2008 and 2011 found many salamanders, with little indication of decline in numbers (T. Papenfuss and S. Rovito pers. comm. 2008, J.M. Solis, F. Castañeda, and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from Parque Nacional Montaña Santa Bárbara, in western Honduras, from 1,825 to 2,750 m asl (McCranie and Castañeda 2007). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 62 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the protected area, Parque Nacional Montaña Santa Bárbara. A short-term project (2019-2020) funded by USAID is raising awareness for endangered species, habitat management and water management in Parque Nacional Montana de Santa Barbara (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). A local NGO, Montaña de Vida, is raising awareness about the habitat in the northern portion of Parque Nacional Montana de Santa Barbara (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). 

Research Needed
Studies into the population ecology and reproduction of this species are needed (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 670 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in north-central Honduras.
habitat: This species lives in low vegetation, moss, and on the ground and tree trunks in premontane wet and lower montane forest. It is not a bromeliad specialist, but is occasionally found in them. It is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Breeding takes place by direct development. Clutch sizes range from 5-19 eggs, and eggs have been laid and observed in abandoned hummingbird nests (McCranie and Wilson 1992).
threats:
Major threats to this species include extensive habitat loss for coffee plantations, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, the creation of roads for coffee plantations and logging, and the subsequent erosion and pollution caused by coffee farming and logging. The reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

In Montaña Macuzal, the habitat has been destroyed by large-scale cattle ranching, small-holder agriculture (crops), and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is an uncommon species, and is not encountered often (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). When it is found, it is only one or two individuals (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). In general, no population changes have been directly observed (F. Castañeda pers. comm. 2007, J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously thought to occur from five localities in north-central Honduras, in the departments of Atlántida, Yoro, and Cortes, between 860-1,990 m asl. However, following genetic and morphological analysis, subpopulations from Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texíguat in Atlántida Department have now been assigned to Nototriton nelsoni, and subpopulations from Cerro Búfalo in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito have be assigned to N. oreadorum (Townsend 2016). This species has now been restricted to the Sierra de Sulaco: Montaña Macuzal and Parque Nacional Pico Pijol in Yoro Department, Honduras, between 1,524-1,920 m asl (Townsend 2016). The subpopulation in Cortes was previously uncertain, however it has now been assigned to N. limnospectator (Townsend 2016) and removed from this species distribution map. It is endemic to Sierra de Sulaco and is highly unlikely to be found more widely, or between the intervening areas as there is no suitable habitat (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Its EOO is 670 km2, which represents two threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Pico Pijol. 

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection is urgently needed in Montaña Macuzal (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). It is currently unprotected, with less than 2 km2 of forest is remaining, and the current status of that forest is unknown (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta is managed by two regional ICF offices that are relatively well positioned for park management; additional resources should be directed to these offices to increase their effectiveness (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Proactive, precautionary steps should also be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Further research is required on effective population size (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 488 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals occur in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in north-central Honduras.
habitat: This semi-fossorial species has been found inside and underneath rotten logs, inside ferns, and inside rocks on the floor of lower montane wet forest near streams (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). The forest where this species occurs consists of a mixture of pine and hardwood species (mixed cloud forest; J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It is unlikely to be tolerant of habitat modification as it has only been recorded in primary forest (J.M. Solís, E. Boza, and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It breeds by direct development.
threats:
At Cataguana in Parque Nacional Montaña de Yoro, the species' habitat is threatened by ongoing deforestation for marijuana plantations (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). As a result of the decree, coffee plantations are increasing inside Parque Nacional Montaña de Yoro and Parque Nacional La Muralla (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). The remaining habitat of this species is threatened by encroaching subsistence agriculture and livestock grazing activities (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

As of 2016, a native boring pine beetle had devastated the pine forests of the region where this species occurs, which encourages widespread harvesting of the dying timber for energy production; increased intentional fires to eliminate the excess biomass; and subsequent conversion of burned areas to cropland. The destruction of the forests by the beetle had ceased as of 2019, but another outbreak will likely occur in the future during the next El Niño cycle (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: It is generally uncommon, although it can be found in reasonable numbers in suitable habitat. For example, four to five individuals have been encountered over three days of surveys in April 2017 (dry season) in Cerro de En Medio (E. Boza pers. comm. March 2019). At Cataguana in Parque Nacional Montaña de Yoro, the species is uncommon to locally common: one juvenile and two adults were recorded in June 2006 and March 2007 and a single adult was observed in September 2008 (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). The species is semi-fossorial and difficult to find, which may reflect the low encounter rate in Parque Nacional Montaña de Yoro (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). The subpopulation in Parque Nacional Montaña de Yoro is thought to be declining due to ongoing decline in its habitat (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). The subpopulation in Cerro de En Medio is thought to be relatively stable (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019).
range: This species was previously only known only from the type locality in Cerro de En Medio in Parque Nacional la Muralla, Department of Olancho, north-central Honduras, between 1,760-1,780 m asl.
