March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is infrequently encountered, and it is often only single individuals that are found (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from the vicinity of Cerro Búfalo in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, Atlántida Department, Honduras, between 1,210-1,540 m asl (Townsend 2016). It is also known from a single specimen (collected in 2013) from the south side of Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios, at 1,200 m asl (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). It is not thought to occur more widely (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in a one threat-defined location, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 91 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios. 

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta is managed by two regional ICF offices that are relatively well positioned for park management; additional resources should be directed to these offices to increase their effectiveness (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Further studies are needed on population, distribution and ecology (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: The Namdapha Flying Squirrel is assessed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence is estimated to be less than 100 km² based on available habitat in the park and on survey data (Molur et al. 2005), it is known from only one location, and its habitat is continuing to decline.
habitat: It is a mostly crepuscular and arboreal species. It occurs in dry deciduous montane forests occupying moist forest tracts along streams (Molur et al. 2005).
threats: Poaching of animals for food within the park has been observed to be the major threat (Molur et al. 2005). The species appears to have a restricted range, with presumably some general habitat loss and degradation taking place. Additional important threats include habitat loss through landslides and flooding (Molur et al. 2005).
population: This appears to be a rare species, and is thought to have a very small population. Nothing known about population trends. It is known only from the holotype specimen collected in 1981, although informal sightings occurred in 2002 near Halidibari and Deban (Molur et al. 2005).
range: This species is only known with certainty from a single specimen collected in Namdapha National Park (at altitudes of 100-350 m asl), Tirap District, Arunachal Pradesh, northeastern India (Saha 1981). The surrounding area has been well surveyed but there have been no verified sightings of the species since (Saha pers. comm). It might be restricted to the area of a single valley within the park (Molur et al. 2005).
useTrade: Biswamoyopterus biswasi is a local livelihood and it is used as food by humans.
conservationActions: The species is not protected by any legislation. It is known from Namdapha National Park, Arunachal Pradesh, India (Molur et al. 2005). There is a need to maintain suitable areas of habitat for this species, and to undertake detailed field surveys to determine whether the species still persists and to determine the current distribution range (Molur et al. 2005).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable due to a small population size estimated to be between 2,500–10,000 mature individuals that is at risk of a projected decline of at least 10% over the next 9–12 years (three generation lengths). All mature individuals are within a single subpopulation.
habitat: This species inhabits grassland habitats surrounded by shrub forests. The species seems to have a degree of tolerance of disturbance as it has been found in secondary forest and areas where the forest has been cut or burned. Adults typically inhabit lentic ponds and wetland habitats, with pond availability being of particular importance during the breeding season. The breeding season for this species is expected to occur around June-July (Hernandez 2016). This species breeds by larval development, and individuals can be found both day and night congregating in small pools and marshes to mate and lay eggs. The primary prey sources for this species are small aquatic pests and molluscs.
threats: This species is restricted to a relatively small area that is threatened by a number of human activities, including expansion of agriculture and livestock farming. High demand for forest products, such as bamboo shoots and firewood, also causes disturbances and leads to over-exploitation of the habitat and resources at certain times each year. The species is also collected for Traditional Chinese medicine – it is not targeted in particular, but used because it resembles other species used for similar purposes (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019). Additionally, this species is threatened by climate change, as it has led to an increase in natural disasters throughout the species' range, such as mud- and landslides. Within a broader context, economic development within the surrounding region has led to increased demands for electricity and natural resources such as coal, which has both encroached and increased pollution effects on the landscape (Hernandez 2016). There are also hydroelectric projects in the area, but these are not affecting the elevations at which the species occurs (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).
population: This species is locally common, but it is believed to be highly restricted and its population is very small. Its population size is estimated to be less than 10,000, but more than 2,500 mature individuals (D.-Q. Rao and F. Xie pers. comm. June 2019). No declines have been observed to date; however, due to ongoing collection pressure and other human activities in the area, the species remains at risk of decline (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019). All individuals are located in a single subpopulation, making the population at risk of a projected decline of at least 10% over the next 9–12 years (3 generation lengths). The average age at first reproduction in this species is estimated to be 3–4 years (D.-Q. Rao. pers. comm June 2019).
range: This species is known only from a single summit in the Ningnan county part of the Daliang Mountains, Sichuan province, China, where it occurs at an elevational range of 2,300–2,800 m asl. It is thought to be restricted to suitable elevations, containing water bodies that this species requires, at the type locality and its immediate area (D.-Q. Rao and F. Xie pers. comm. June 2019).
useTrade: This species is sometimes collected for Traditional Chinese medicine – it is not targeted in particular, but is sometimes used because it resembles other species used for similar purposes (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species was afforded Status-II protection in China under its previous identity within the wider concept of Tylotriton verrucosus from which it was split (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019). The summit on which the species occurs is not within any protected areas. 

Conservation Needed
This species would benefit from improved habitat protection and management at sites where it is known to occur.

Research Needed
Surveys to determine the current distribution of this species and its population size, status and trends are recommended. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the variety of threats that exist within the species' small range.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of 327 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur at two locations (the northern part of the Knuckles, with greater impacts from tourism and higher vulnerability to climate change; and the southern part, where the main threat is encroachment), and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat as a result of these threats.
habitat: This species is found in moist tropical montane cloud forest, as well as abandoned cardamom plantations (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). These authors report that it is found in home gardens, but this is considered to refer to isolated houses within forest rather than true cultivated areas. It is arboreal and generally found on moss-covered tree trunks, but has also been observed on low bushes, cardamom plants and lianas (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). Females lay 2-4 eggs in a clutch (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). This region receives more than 2,000 mm of precipitation each year.
threats: This species is restricted to the Knuckles mountain range, most of which is currently not protected or subject to conservation management (Bahir and Surasinghe 2005), and which has largely been converted to tea, pine and rubber cultivation. In the 1960s, the vast majority of the remaining forest in the Knuckles Hills was underplanted with cardamom. This process has left the canopy in good condition, but the regeneration of natural forest has been almost completely inhibited (Manamendra-Arachchi and Liyanage 1994), and active management of cardamom plantation - including illegal burning - and the removal of understorey and small trees for fuel are ongoing. Tourist development is ongoing, often illegally within former cardamom plantations. Localized landslides in forest, a consequence of water diversion and clearance of forest at higher elevations, disturb or destroy this lizard's habitat. Invasive mist flower (Ageratina riparia) is expanding through cardamom plantations into otherwise natural forest, reducing the availability of oviposition sites, and the species is rare within or absent from areas where this plant has become established. This species is most common in moist, high elevation forest where the impacts of drought, especially in the drier north, are likely to be most pronounced. Forest dieback (the causes of which remain poorly-understood but have been linked to lead pollution - Ranasinghe et al. 2009) has been observed at known localities (N. Perera pers. comm. 2019). The Knuckles Range is a major locality for pet trade collection, and habitat destruction has been observed in forested areas as a result of efforts to collect this and other species.
population: This species is still fairly common in natural habitat and cardamom plantations. Declines have been reported in some areas both within and outside protected areas, including Riverston, as a result of land clearance or habitat degradation. It is rare or absent where the invasive mist flower has become established.
range: This species is endemic to the Knuckles Range in central Sri Lanka at elevations of 700 to 1,200 m asl. (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). The range encompasses approximately 175 km<sup>2</sup> (Manamendra-Arachchi and Liyanage 1994).
useTrade: This species has been recorded in the US pet trade since 2016, including imports from Europe of animals advertised as both wild-caught and captive-bred (LEMIS 2017). Janssen and de Silva (2019) recorded 40 online advertisements for this species in Europe and the US in 2017 and 2018, and suggested that this volume may represent a smuggling event. Animals observed in trade commonly appear to have less prominent horns than the natural population, which is likely to increase demand to supplement captive-bred animals in trade with those sourced from the wild (S. Wikramanyake and D. Samarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions: This species is known from the Knuckles Conservation Forest. but although a conservation management plan is in place illegal encroachment for agriculture is ongoing. There is a need to better-regulate these activities, as well as to managing cardamom plantations in an effort to prevent further expansion of invasive mist flower. While export and collection of this species has been prohibited since 1993, there is a need to improve enforcement to prevent smuggling of this and other species. It was listed in 2019 on CITES Appendix I.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species has an extremely restricted range in two small patches of degraded habitat, treated as a single location defined by a plausible future threat from climate change. Although the known localities are disturbed, the species has persisted here for over a century and the population is apparently stable. It is however a member of a group that appears to be highly sensitive to changes in moisture regimes, and other areas of Sri Lanka have experienced extended periods of drought with greater frequency in recent years. This is likely to be an imminent threat to this species, and should this area become substantially drier this gecko will warrant immediate listing as Critically Endangered and may become Extinct. A secondary threat exists from possible future land conversion, which is thought to be less immediately likely but which will probably result in the immediate extinction of this gecko should this threat become active.
habitat: This species is known from small, preserved patches of forest with large trees which are associated with bungalows in tea plantations, but is absent from open tea plantations. It is associated with rocks and boulders and requires shaded areas. Communal nesting has been recorded (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009).
threats: This species is confined to working tea plantations, which have been subject to increased use of agrochemicals over the past 20 years although no decline has yet been observed based on surveys as recent as 2018 (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019). There is no protection for these localities and any change in habitat management practices could immediately threaten this species with extinction, although at present there is no particular pressure in this area to convert tea into other uses. This species is associated with humid conditions, and while this area is so far not as heavily impacted as other areas of Sri Lanka by drought, an extended drought may be sufficient to drive this species to extinction and these events are expected to become more frequent. This species may be especially vulnerable as there is no remaining natural habitat in the surrounding area that could preserve a moist microhabitat. It occurs in high gradient areas where landslips are common.
population: This species is common and the population appears to be stable at the known localities, which are already-disturbed sites outside protected areas that were converted to tea plantations more than a century ago. It is however unknown whether it was formerly more widespread, or the scale and timing of any past decline.
range: This species is endemic to Sri Lanka's wet zone, where it occurs at high elevations in the central hills (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). Following Agarwal et al. (2017) it is known only from Nanu Oya and Pussellawa, at 900-1,600 m asl.
useTrade: There is not thought to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The possibility of buying the known localities and preserving then as a conservation area should be investigated. Research into effects of pesticides and climate change, and surveys of remnant forest patches in surrounding area are recommended, but there is no extensive natural habitat. More research on this species' ecology to clarify how this species survived a century in the absence of natural habitat and to inform habitat-based management such as control of pesticide use. Raise awareness of importance of this gecko among current owners of plantations.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Critically Endangered because of an observed population decline, estimated to be more than 80% over the past 10 years, inferred from the impact of chytridiomycosis on this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Critically Endangered because of population decline, estimated to be more than 80% over the past 10 years, inferred from the complete destruction of its forest habitat at Mesilau on Mt. Kinabulu due to high-magnitude earthquake and subsequent landslides in 2015.
habitat: Adults disperse widely over the floor of montane and submontane forests. It breeds in small, clear, rocky-bottomed streams and larvae live in torrents, clinging to rocks and feeding on lithophytes. It appears to be unable to adapt to modified habitats.
threats: In 2015, earthquakes caused major landslides at Mesilau, within Kinabalu National Park, where the species was known to occur (Earth Observatory 2017, P. Yambun pers. comm. January 2018). If the species still occurs at Mesilau, the species could be threatened by the development of roads and facilities for tourism within the park (P. Yambun pers. comm. January 2018).
population: In the 2004 assessment it was considered to be locally very abundant, particularly in the form of tadpoles. However, in 2015 earthquakes and subsequent landslides completely wiped out the species' habitat at Mesilau, which are thought to have caused significant population declines of at least 80% (P. Yambun pers. comm. January 2018). A short survey was conducted at Mesilau in 2017 by A. Haas, and no individuals were found, however additional surveys are required (P. Yambun pers. comm. January 2018). There is a possibility that this species is extinct.
range: This species is endemic to a portion of montane north-western Sabah, Malaysia in northern Borneo. A large subpopulation occurs in the vicinity of Mesilau in Kinabalu National Park between 1,600 and 2,000 m asl. It is possible that the species occurs more widely within the park, but there are no records yet (P. Yambun pers. comm. January 2018). There are reports of another small subpopulation on Mount Trus Madi at 1,300 m asl, however additional surveys are needed to confirm this. Attempts to locate the species on Gunung Mulu in Sarawak have not been successful.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs in Kinabalu National Park, which is well protected.

Conservation Needed
There is a particular need to expand the existing protected area network (especially above 1,200 m asl) south of Kinabalu National Park. 

Research Needed
Additional surveys are needed to determine whether the species occurs at other sites within Kinabalu National Park.

rationale: Poecilia bosemani is known only from its type locality in the Maraval River on the island of Trinidad, Trinidad and Tobago. Given the lack of reliable georeferenced collection records, it is not possible to accurately estimate Extent of Occurrence (EOO), Area of Occupancy (AOO), or the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs. Total population size and population trend are unknown. A number of threats to the integrity of the Maraval River are present, including sedimentation and erosion associated with rapid population growth, agricultural practices, and unplanned urban development. Given these uncertainties, it is not possible to directly or indirectly estimate the extinction risk of this species. Therefore, P. boesemani is assessed as Data Deficient until more information becomes available.
habitat: This species is known only from the Maraval River on the island of Trinidad (Phillip et al. 2013). Fertilization occurs internally, with females giving live birth (Phillip et al. 2013). This species tolerates brackish and full strength seawater (Phillip et al. 2013). Maximum reported body size is approximately 4 cm (Phillip et al. 2013).
threats:
The Maraval River is subject to a moderate volume of anthropogenic pollutants (Norville 2005). It flows through Maraval, a suburb approximately 4 miles north of the capital city Port of Spain, which has a population of approximately 10,000 individuals that is growing rapidly due to emigration from adjacent towns (Martin et al. 2016). The result has been a considerable expansion of unplanned settlements especially on the hillsides, generating deforestation, soil erosion, landslides and consequently increased incidences of flooding (Martin et al. 2016). Small-holder agriculture has been historically practiced on the hillslopes of the Maraval Valley since at least the 1800s, and erosion in this watershed was documented as early as the 1950s (Moore 1951). These land-use changes have undoubtedly impacted habitat quality and availability within the Maraval River drainage.

The non-native Gourami Trichopodus trichopterus is established in many drainages throughout Trinidad, and may compete with native ichthyofaunal communities for resources (Mohammed et al. 2010). However, the direct impacts on P. boesemani are unknown.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown.
range:
Poecilia bosemani is known only from its type locality in the Maraval River on the island of Trinidad, Trinidad and Tobago (Poeser 2003, Phillip et al. 2013). Distribution may extend to adjacent mainland Venezuela (Phillip et al. 2013), but has not been reported from this area to date (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009). Additional genetic analysis on subpopulations currently recognized as P. sphenops around Diego Martin and St. Augustine will be necessary to determine the range extent of P. boesemani (Phillip et al. 2013).

Given the lack of reliable georeferenced collection records, it is not possible to accurately estimate Extent of Occurrence (EOO), Area of Occupancy (AOO), or the number of threat-based locations where this species occurs.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards P. boesemani. Given the lack of georeferenced collection localities, it is not known if the range of this species extends into any protected areas. Additional ichthyological sampling is needed to accurately determine the distribution of this species. Further information regarding population size, population trend, and the scope and magnitude of existing threats is needed to clarify the conservation status of this species.

rationale: The Daintree Rainbowfish is assessed as Critically Endangered. This species has a restricted range within the Daintree region of Queensland, Australia, with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 12 km2. It occurs at a single location based on the threats of invasive species, water extraction and habitat loss. There are continuing declines in the area of occupancy (AOO), EOO, habitat quality and the number of mature individuals, inferred as a result of these threats.
habitat:
This species typically inhabits small clear shaded rainforest streams flowing over mixed rock, sand, gravel and log debris. They are often found in deeper pools in area of high flow and swim near the surface to midwater depth. This species presumably feeds on terrestrial invertebrates taken from the surface. This species has been found to sometimes school with other rainbowfish species. Presumably this species breeds from August to October, with females depositing batches of eggs amongst root masses.

The species has extremely specialised habitat requirements (Barclay and Martin 2013; Hammer et al. 2018). It is found only in small tributary streams of Cooper and Hutchinson Creeks. There is only one record (two individuals) from the main reach of these streams and it appears that the species avoids the main stream channels possibly because of increased habitat instability and increased predatory pressure from larger fish species in those areas. The streams where it occurs are small (<5 m wide and generally less than 1 m deep), clear and shaded rainforest streams which have permanent flow charged from springs on the nearby Thornton Peak (one of the highest rainfall sites in Australia). Substrates in the area include granite boulders and alluvium deposits of gravel and sand, with no instream aquatic vegetation.

The species is most common in stream reaches closest to the foothills/plains interface. It congregates in high flow areas, such as areas immediately up or downstream of riffles or small waterfalls, where it has been observed feeding on terrestrial invertebrates on the surface, or capturing small prey swept by in the current. Local water extraction could alter flow regimes.
threats:
This species has an extremely small population size and occupied area. This in itself could lead to a rapid extinction event if a major local perturbation was experienced.

Permanent stream flow appears to be a critical habitat requirement for this species. Any reduction or loss of permanent stream flow could be a serious, potentially catastrophic threat to populations. This threat could occur due to climate change, extended drought, excessive water extraction, or most likely a combination of these effects (i.e. demand for water is greatest in times of low rainfall and streamflow, especially during drought). Regulated and unregulated water extraction activities occur on all sites.

Known populations occur on private land, including hobby farms, tourist developments and small scale horticulture, although much of the riparian zone in these areas is maintained in a natural rainforest condition (canopy at least). Landuse change/clearing and introduced terrestrial species like pigs are considered as threats. Pigs destroy bankside vegetation and modify bankside and in stream soil structure, leading to erosion during flood events and siltation of habitats.

There are currently no exotic or translocated species populations in the areas where this fish occurs. However, exotic species such as Tilapia, and translocated native species such as grunters (Hephaestus spp.) have been widely introduced in the Wet Tropics bioregion and are likely to threaten Cairnsichthys populations if they became established in the area. Both catchments where the species occurs are crossed by public roads.

Chance or accidental chemical spills in the area could affect populations, since all sites are on private property. Natural landslides occur on the steep catchment area (Thornton Peak) and severely impacted one site in 2018.
population:
The population dynamics for this species are unknown. This species occurs in a restricted region.

There are no published data on populations. Field surveys in 2017-18 recorded a minimum of approximately 150 mature individuals over the four main sites where the species is present. The species appears to be no longer present at one separate location where it was reported in 2003 (Thuesen 2004, F. Kroon pers. comm. 2013, Barclay and Martin 2013, Hammer et al. 2018).

The species is uncommon at all known sites and is usually recorded as individuals or small groups. The largest group observed to date was of 12 mature individuals (K. Martin unpublished data).
range: The Daintree Rainbowfish is currently known only from the Cooper and Hutchinson creek systems in the Daintree region of the Queensland Wet Tropics, where it is only known from one basin and three sub-populations in small tributaries. The total length of stream where the species had been recorded in 2018 was about 1,200 m. There is an unconfirmed earlier record (2003) of the species in a Forest Creek tributary (also in the Daintree region) but recent surveys have been unable to relocate the species there (Barclay and Martin 2013, Hammer et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species would make a suitable aquarium subject but there has been no indication of any trade activity.
conservationActions:
Research into potential threats, life history (e.g. nursery habitats) and current population data is necessary.

There are currently no formal conservation measures in place. All sites are located on private property and informal approaches have been made to some property owners. One of the properties is owned by a private conservation group. The local National Parks office has been informally notified of the species presence in the area.

The main conservation action required is to maintain existing locations in a natural condition and ensure that potential threatening processes are reduced or eliminated (e.g. pro-active invasive species control). This would involve liaison with property owners to reach agreement on management actions. Regular monitoring of sites should be undertaken to identify threats, check on management and document changes in fish populations.

Security populations should be established offsite to ensure continued survival of the species should a catastrophic event occur.

rationale: This species qualifies as Endangered because it is restricted to one very small area when breeding, and its habitat is declining in quality due to erosion and landslips.
habitat: Behaviour The species is a colonial, winter breeder. Most eggs are laid in late May, and hatch mostly in mid to late July. Chicks fledge from November to December (ACAP 2012). In any given year, a large proportion of the population skip breeding; however, there is no discernible pattern to this behaviour, although it maybe linked to El Niño events (Waugh et al. 2006). Skipped breeders have lower survival rates, possibly owing to differences in the 'fitness' of individuals. Juveniles return to the colony as young as three years, but the age of first breeding is 7.5 years (Waugh et al. 2015a). During incubation and chick-rearing, satellite-tracking data indicate foraging principally on the continental slope off the West Coast of South Island, but birds regularly visit Cook Strait, the Chatham Rise and Fiordland, and frequently forage in the mid-Tasman sea (Freeman et al. 1997, 2001). Habitat Breeding They nest on densely forested hills at 20-250 m. Burrows are usually concentrated in areas where the ground is relatively open, and where take-off areas are close by. This is one of the few remaining petrels still nesting on mainland New Zealand, possibly due to more aggressively resisting attacks from land-based predators (Brooks 2011). Diet Fisheries waste is an important dietary component, perhaps forming more than half of solid food fed to chicks during the hoki fishing season (Freeman 1998). Subsequent satellite tracking studies have suggested that dietary analysis over-estimates the amount of food scavenged from trawlers and that the species continues to forage over wider areas than those occupied by the hoki fishery. Even individuals known to forage at fishing fleets acquire a large proportion of their food elsewhere (Freeman et al. 2001, Freeman and Wilson 2002).
threats:
The Westland Petrel is at risk from introduced species. A population of feral pigs has established within 20km of the breeding colonies, leading to concerns that, if the pigs discover the colonies, they will predate adults and cause habitat degradation, an issue that is exacerbated by their difficulty of eradication (Waugh and Wilson 2017). Feral dogs are present at locations very close to the breeding colonies, and vagrant dogs have killed petrels at the colonies previously (Waugh and Wilson 2017). Other predatory introduced mammals sighted in and around the colonies during 2010-2016 include Brushtail Possums, stoats Mustela ermine and rats Rattus spp. Nevertheless, productivity is relatively high, with around 65% of eggs laid fledging chicks (Waugh et al. 2015, Waugh and Wilson 2017), suggesting that their presence may not hinder breeding success. Cats Felis catus are considered a more significant threat and most chick deaths recorded in the 1990s were attributed to cat predation (Wilson 2016), however the levels of predation appear low and do appear to be causing a population decline.

Habitat loss and degradation is also a threat. In the past, farming may have destroyed some habitat, but presently the colonies are situated on land that is too steep and difficult to access for agriculture. In 2014 tropical storm Ita destroyed or damaged up to half of the area of assessed colonies, which contained up to 75% of the breeding population (Waugh et al. 2015). Severe erosion following the storm continues to cause the loss of burrows (Waugh and Wilson 2017).

At sea these petrels overlap considerably with fisheries (Waugh et al. 2018) and their ecological niche widens in El Niño years, indicating that food type is affected by climatic variation (Waugh et al. 2018). Non-breeders, which spend considerable time off South America, demonstrated reduced survivorship compared to breeding individuals. This is thought to be due to the effects of bycatch, both commercial and subsistence. The behaviourally (and visually) similar Black Petrel is killed as bycatch in artisanal fisheries off Ecuador and Peru (Mangel 2012) indicating that small-scale fisheries may be a significant source of mortality. Bycatch also occurs within the foraging range of breeding birds, and the species is considered at high risk of adverse population effects here also (Richard and Abraham 2015).

Human exploitation is likely to occur, with equipment used to extract chicks from burrows found in 2011, but any take is considered likely to be very limited (Waugh and Wilson 2017). The 'fallout', attraction of petrels (especially fledglings) to lights at night, may be an important threat for the species, as it causes mortality through direct collisions and grounding, although the level of mortality is unknown (Waugh and Wilson 2017).
population:
The most recent estimate of population size is 2,954-5,137 annual breeding pairs (Wood and Otley 2013), but given that not all individuals breed each year this is likely to be an underestimate for the number of mature individuals. Assuming that 25% of breeding age birds may skip breeding in any one year (as derived from long-term data sets on similar species) (B. Baker in litt. 2012), the population size is estimated at 7,877-13,698 mature individuals, rounded here to 7,900-13,700 mature individuals.

Following the tropical storm Ita in 2014, there was considerable damage to the breeding area, with the loss or damage of up to 50% of the major colonies, which contain up to 75% of the breeding population (Waugh et al. 2015b). Fortunately, the storm occurred before the laying period and so adults may not have been killed in their nests, unless they were visiting prior to breeding (which some birds have been reported to do) (S. Waugh in litt. 2016), and some birds have moved between impacted colonies (S. Waugh in litt. 2016). Therefore, the level of destruction may not equate to any decline in population, and no population data subsequent to the storm are yet available, though surveys are currently underway (S. Waugh in litt. 2016).
range: Procellaria westlandica breeds in the densely forested coastal foothills near Punakaiki, South Island, New Zealand (Best and Owen 1976). It migrates in summer to central Pacific and eastern New Zealand waters, the east coast of Australia and off South America (Marchant and Higgins 1990, Brinkley et al. 2000), and is regularly recorded off the coast of Chile extending into the South Atlantic to the east of Tierra del Fuego (Spear et al. 2005). A large number were recorded in the area of the Golfo de Penas (400 individuals) and Canal Messier (850 individuals), Aisen (Chile), and all in heavy primary moult (Fraser 2009), potentially representing 10% of the world population of this species (Fraser 2009).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
CMS Appendix II and ACAP Annex 1. The breeding site is within the Paparoa National Park. The breeding colonies were designated as Westland Petrel Special Area in 1999, which restricts public access. A long-term study has been in place since 1969, covering social organisation, behaviour, breeding biology and aspects of population dynamics. A demographic study was undertaken between 1995 and 2003 (Waugh et al. 2006). Monitoring is being undertaken to check for the presence of pigs and dogs in the petrel habitat (S. Freeman pers. comm. per Waugh and Wilson 2017). Work is ongoing to raise awareness of the risks of lights and power line strikes among local residents so that downed petrels may be recovered and released (Waugh and Wilson 2017).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Census all burrows every 10 years, continue annual monitoring of study burrows, and band chicks and adults. Identify and minimise hazards to birds flying to and from the colony. Carry out predator control and monitoring of nests to identify predation events, and respond accordingly, and carry out sustained control of browsing mammals, particularly goats and possums. Exclude stock and dogs from colonies (Taylor 2000), e.g. with fencing, bait stations or management of buffer land (Waugh and Wilson 2017). Ensure that local people are aware of the risk posed by dogs (Wilson 2016). Minimise the impact of tourist infrastructure through planning control (K.-J. Wilson in litt. 2008). Maintain vigilance in assessing seabird-fisheries interaction data in New Zealand and other areas to ensure that changes in fisheries operations, gear types and areas of activity do not lead to concomitant changes in bycatch (B. Baker in litt. 2012). Enforce standards around lighting and structures (Waugh and Wilson 2017). Research impact of light pollution on the population (Wilson 2016). Monitor whether human harvest is taking place (Waugh and Wilson 2017).

rationale: Listed as Endangered given that its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 1,706 km<sup>2</sup>, it is considered to occur in three threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat within and surrounding the protected areas where it occurs in Honduras and Guatemala.
habitat: This species lives in premontane and lower montane moist forest and is found in arboreal bromeliads, on low vegetation, and under rotten trees in the ground. It prefers intact forest and can be found on forest edge, but not in degraded habitats. Breeding takes place by direct development and the species is not dependent upon water.
threats:
The main threat is loss of habitat for subsistence and small-scale agriculture, cattle grazing, logging and human settlement. Logging pressure and contamination from communities within and around Sierra Caral, Guatemala still represent threats there (C. Vásquez-Almazán pers. comm. 2019).

The reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The cultivation of cardamom, coffee, and flowers is taking place within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cusuco and Reserva de Merendón (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another major threat is an increase in intentional human-induced fires for clearing of habitat for agriculture (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). Increasing human settlements and selective logging are causing habitat loss within the parks (J. Kolby, F. Castañeda, J.M. Solís, L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of this fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Mesoamerica (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019).
population: In Honduras, this species is locally common, but appears to have declined in the Parque Nacional Cerro Azul due to intensive habitat loss (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In the 1990s and early 2000s, this species used to be common in Sierra Caral (M. Acevedo pers. comm. August 2019), however, it is now considered to be uncommon there, where during <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">20 nights of sampling between 2008-2011 there were only two records (C. Vásquez-Almazán pers. comm. 2014). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from three locations in Guatemala and Honduras defined as such by extensive and ongoing habitat loss: (1) the eastern mountains of the Atlantic versant of Guatemala (mountains of Sierra de Caral); (2) Parque Nacional Cerro Azul in Copán Department, Honduras; and (3) Parque Nacional Cusuco and the surrounding Merendón Mountains west of San Pedro Sula in Cortés Department, Honduras. In Guatemala, the species is considered to occur only in the Sierra Caral (C. Vásquez-Almazán pers. comm. 2014), but it is expected to occur slightly more widely in Honduras, particularly in Santa Barbara Department (J.M. Solís and F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Its known elevational range is 1,200–1,600 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,706 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
In Guatemala, this species occurs in Reserva Protector de Manantiales Sierra Caral. In Honduras, it occurs in Parque Nacional Cusuco, Parque Nacional Cerro Azul, and Reserva de Merendón. Parque Nacional Cusuco is one of the few areas of Honduras that has regular patrolling by park rangers supported by Panthera and Operation Wallacea; the rangers patrol the southern portion of the park and effectively report any illegal activities (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Operation Wallacea has been conducting annual biodiversity monitoring in Parque Nacional El Cusuco since 2005 (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). UNAH-VS and the environmental division of San Pedro Sula municipality are conducting biodiversity monitoring of Merendón water production forest and building capacity in the area, and has plans to extend this to Parque Nacional El Cusuco (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The municipality of San Pedro Sula has an active ranger team protecting the watersheds and fighting forest fires in the Merendón water production forest and the southern portion of Parque Nacional El Cusuco (L. Herrera and F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a need for improved protection in Sierra Caral in Guatemala. Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Mesoamerica and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities (Honduras and Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshops 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). 

Research Needed
Additional studies are needed to better understand this species' life history and population status.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is 17,954 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in northeastern Honduras.
habitat: This species is found in pristine broadleaf forest with a closed canopy and in secondary broadleaf forest with a partially open canopy, in the Lowland Moist Forest formation (McCranie et al. 2008). All individuals were found among leaf litter or under rotten logs during the day (McCranie et al. 2008; J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). At night, individuals are active and found along streams (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). It is unlikely to be tolerant of habitat disturbance (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It breeds by direct development and is not dependent upon water for reproduction.
threats:
Although this species occurs in the Río Plátano Biosphere Reserve, forest destruction throughout this species' range, mainly as a result of agricultural expansion and extensive cattle ranching mainly fueled by drug trafficking and illegal selective logging for hardwoods, is nonetheless rampant and causing a decrease in available habitat for this species (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

The area from which this species occurs in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Nombre de Dios is subject to extensive landslides; these often impact the species' habitat. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of cacao in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is generally uncommon within its relatively wide range, but it is locally common in La Mosquitia and Parque Nacional Pico Bonito (J. Ramos Galdámez and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species range extends from just south of La Ceiba, Atlántida Department (Parques Nacionales Nombre de Dios and Pico Bonito), to Quebrada de Las Marias, Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta and Las Canoas and Río Cuaca in Olancho Department, eastward and southeastward to the Río Coco drainage system, and Reserva Biológica Río Plantano and La Mosquitia in Colón and Gracias a Dios Departments of northeastern Honduras, between 70-1,180 m asl (McCranie et al. 2008, Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Records previously assigned to Oedipina cyclocauda have now been assigned to this species (J. Townsend and M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It is likely to occur on the Nicaraguan side of the Río Coco, as there is suitable habitat there (McCranie et al. 2008). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 17,954 km2, which represents 10 or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in Parque Nacionales Sierra de Agalta, Pico Bonito and Nombre de Dios, as well as, Reserva Biológica Río Plátano.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). 

Research Needed
More surveys are needed to better understand this species' natural history and population status (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 43 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from only one location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat at its only known location in and around Parque Nacional Pico Bonito in Honduras.
habitat: This species is a leaf litter dwelling frog with similarities to Craugastor laticeps. It inhabits broadleaf forests in regions that are drier than required for many other Craugastor species. This species is not streamside dependent, unlike many species in the genus (McCranie 2018). There is no information on its breeding ecology but is assumed to be a direct developer like other species in the genus.
threats:
The forests of Quebrada de Oro were largely in pristine condition in 1980 (McCranie 2018). However, shortly afterwards, anthropogenic habitat alteration of those forests began. Subsequently, Hurricane Mitch struck the region in October 1998, the hillsides collapsed into giant mudslides that buried the Quebrada de Oro and destroyed the forests that remained on the slopes from 1,000 m asl and below (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). The closed-canopy gallery forests have not recovered as of 2005, and the stream itself passed through open areas of boulders (McCranie pers. obs in McCranie 2018). 

At present, major threats to this species still include deforestation as a result of agricultural and livestock encroachment, human settlements, logging, fires and landslides inside Parque Nacional Pico Bonito (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core part of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, which may create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antuñez, J. Ramos Galdámez, J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: This species is naturally rare (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Concentrated survey efforts have produced only two known specimens, both of which were males. The first specimen was collected in the 1980s by J.R. McCranie and the second specimen was collected in 2005 by F. Castañeda (McCranie 2018). These have been the only specimens encountered in spite of an additional ~60 days of survey effort in the Quebrada de Oro region (in the months of January, February, May, June, and August, encompassing both the rainy and dry seasons between the 1980s and 2005; F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Thus, it appears that the species occurs in low population numbers at that site. Night time collecting efforts have not produced additional specimens. This encounter rate is unusual in Honduras when compared with other species of the Craugastor laticeps group (McCranie 2018). Because there is still plenty of suitable habitat in the same mountain range from where this species is known, additional survey effort is urgently needed in this habitat to confirm whether the species is still surviving (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is endemic to the Quebrada de Oro area of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito in Honduras (McCranie 2018). It has been found at elevations from 1,140–1,270 m asl (McCranie 2018). There are reports of this species from Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios; however, the identity of these records require confirmation through specimen examination (J. Ramos Galdámez and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 43 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents a single threat-defined location.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is only known from the edge of Parque Nacional Pico Bonito.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Research Needed
Further survey work is necessary in suitable habitats in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito to determine whether the species is still extant. If located, studies are needed into this species' natural history and population status (F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Taxonomic work through examination of specimens is needed to verify the reports of this species from Parque Nacional Nombre de Dios.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,880 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in north-central Honduras.
habitat: It inhabits premontane and montane wet tropical forest and is unable to tolerate low-elevation tropical dry forest valleys. Individuals are active in the day in leaf litter of closed-canopy rainforest, well above streams (McCranie 2018). It is unlikely to be tolerant of habitat disturbance. It breeds by direct development.
threats:
The main threat is anthropogenic habitat destruction that has occurred since 1991 on the Yoro side of Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texíguat, and this was likely exacerbated by the effects of Hurricane Mitch (October 1998) which caused major landslides that destroyed the gallery forests and remaining forests on the slopes where the holotype was collected (McCranie 2018).

In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protection de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Articulos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core part of the refuge (which currently is at 1,250 m asl) upslope, which would create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez and J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019).

In Parque Nacional Pico Pijol, major threats to this species include extensive habitat loss for coffee plantations, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, the creation of roads for coffee plantations and logging, and the subsequent erosion and pollution caused by coffee farming and logging.

Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout this species' range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type.
population: At Mezapa in Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texíguat, it is relatively common (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). For example, in 2019, 11 individuals were recorded in one hour during the daytime in Mezapa (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). In 2018, five individuals were recorded in two nights of surveys at Liberación in Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texíguat (C. Antúnez pers. comm. March 2019). Its population status in other sites of its range is unknown; however, the population<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":2}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}"> is suspected to be decreasing due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
range: This species is known from the slopes of Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texíguat in the Cordillera Nombre de Dios in the departments of Yoro and Atlantida; from the eastern slopes of Montaña Pico Pijol; and to the east on Montaña Macuzal near Portillo Grande, and Montañas de Mataderos in Yoro Department, Honduras (McCranie 2018). The mesic montane habitats inhabited by the species are separated by ~100 km of harsh, open, hotter, low-elevation tropical dry forest valleys (McCranie 2018). The known altitudinal range is between 1,000-1,500 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,883 km<sup>2</sup>, which represents five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this speicies being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in two protected areas in Honduras: Reserva de Vida Silvestre Texíguat and Parque Nacional Pico Pijol.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Research Needed
Further research is needed on this species' ecology and populations trends.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable because it has a small range, in which suitable habitat is declining in quantity and quality. The population is very small. The species occurs in two disjunct subpopulations, but the status of one of them is unclear. The species may qualify for a higher threat category in the future.
habitat: The species occupies the understorey of dry, seasonally deciduous montane woodland and forest in rain-shadow valleys at c.1,800-3,300 m (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997, Herzog et al. 1999, Remsen and Sharpe 2018). It may also be found in low, bushy vegetation in cleared areas adjacent to forest (Remsen & Sharpe 2018). Rarely, it ventures into plantations. It has been hypothesised that Bolivian Spinetail depends on the epiphytic ‘grey beard’ bromeliad for nesting (A. Hennessey in litt. 2006). A possible juvenile and apparent pairs have been observed in January, while mixed-species feeding parties are joined in the dry season (the austral winter) (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997, Herzog et al. 1999).
threats: Much suitable habitat has long been destroyed or severely degraded due to anthropogenic impact (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997, S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). For centuries, woodland within the range has been cut for firewood and charcoal production, which greatly reduces the abundance of the ‘grey beard’ bromeliad (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997, S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). Although many older trees with the 'grey beard' bromeliad remain in the Cotojaces basin, habitat regeneration is impeded by heavy overgrazing, burning and clearance for agriculture (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997, S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). The conversion of native vegetation into Eucalyptus plantations, combined with the destruction of native vegetation and high grazing pressure, has caused hydrological changes leading to massive soil erosion  and landslides (S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). The species’s stronghold near Inquisivi in La Paz department may be extirpated by landslides by 2050 or sooner (S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). The expansion of the road network threatens the remaining habitat by facilitating access to the area and exploitation of the forest for charcoal production (S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). Climate change is likely to significantly reduce this species’s range (del Rosario Avalos and Hernández 2015).
population: Field surveys revealed a population density of 168 individuals/km2 (S. K. Herzog in litt. 2013). The area of mapped range covers c.1,390 km2. Assuming that only 1% of this area contains suitable habitat for the species, the extrapolation of the population size results in an estimate of c.2,330 individuals. This roughly equates to 1,500 mature individuals. Given the apparent rarity of the species near Sorata, the population estimate may need to be corrected if more recent survey data from the area becomes available.
range: Cranioleuca henricae occurs in dry valleys on the east slope of the Andes in west Bolivia (Cochabamba and La Paz). The only populations known are in the río Cotacajes basin near Inquisivi and the río Consata basin near Sorata (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997; Herzog et al. 1999; S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). The species has been found to be abundant in the Cotocajes valley (Seeholzer et al. 2015). A record of a Cranioleuca sp. in suitable habitat at Saila Pata in the río Cotacajes basin may be attributable to this species (N. Krabbe per S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999). Records of 1-2 individuals came from Churupampa and nearby Sorata in the río Consata basin (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997, Lowen and Kennedy 1999). Searches in the río Consata basin, where very little suitable habitat remains, have not revealed further localities (S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). The species has not been observed in the past years in the Consata basin and the status of the population there is unclear; however no targeted surveys have been carried out in recent years (S. K. Herzog in litt. 2019). A record from Mecapaca in the upper río La Paz basin is unconfirmed and likely erroneous (S. K. Herzog in litt. 2019).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway

Considered Endangered at the national level in Bolivia (Ministerio de Medio Ambiente y Agua 2009). Targeted searches have resulted in some of the most recent records, but also a number of negative results from apparently suitable habitat (Herzog et al. 1999, S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). It is not currently known from any protected areas (Rocha and Balderrama 2009). Proposals have recently been made to protect the Machaca stronghold by developing a long-term conservation strategy working closely with the local community and involving local environmental education, sustainable development workshops, agricultural assessment and development, and the promotion of the area as a birdwatching attraction; with the eventual aim of protecting a core area as a reserve (S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007).

Conservation Actions Proposed

Carry out further surveys to obtain an improved estimate of the population. Carry out targeted searches in the Consata basin to determine whether the population still persists there. Monitor population trends through regular surveys. Monitor rates of habitat loss and degradation within the species's range. Act to prevent further erosion and landslides below Inquisivi (S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007). Support the maintenance of traditional land-use and tenure systems that allow natural woodland habitats to persist (Maijer and Fjeldså 1997). Establish municipal or private reserves that ensure protection of the best remaining forest patches. Encourage sustainable ethno-ecotourism as a new source of income for local communities that protect forest patches (S. K. Herzog in litt. 1999, 2007).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that, while this species is presently common in suitable habitat, it is restricted to an unprotected area where it has a maximum extent of occurrence little greater than 40 km<sup>2</sup>, it is highly intolerant of habitat degradation, and there is a widespread and rapid continuing decline in the extent and quality of both forest and rocky habitat within its range driven by multiple pressures.
habitat: This species is restricted to granite caves and rock outcrops, in both forest and active rubber plantations (Karunarathna et al. 2019). Natural forest in this area consists of dry mixed semi-evergreen forest (Karunarathna et al. 2019). Mean annual rainfall is between 1,500 and 2,500 mm received mainly during the November-February monsoon (Karunarathna et al. 2019). Animals were found at heights of up to 6 m on vertical surfaces, in "poorly-illuminated", cool and moist microhabitats (Karunarathna et al. 2019). Geckos are active by day (08:00-17:00) and when disturbed retreated either to rocky crevices or beneath leaf litter.
threats: The Maragalakanda area includes a matrix of natural forest, rubber plantations and anthropogenic habitats  (Karunarathna et al. 2019). Expanding rubber plantations (where the species can survive but is less abundant - S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019), and blasting rocks for construction material (which has already observed in some areas at the type locality) represent major threats. Illegal logging is both a direct impact and can result in landslips which destroy both rocky and forest habitat. This reserve is an upland area surrounded by agricultural development at lower elevations, and upslope agricultural encroachment and settlement is ongoing, with area of remaining forest declining observably every year (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019). There is clearance of undergrowth and understorey vegetation for fuelwood. This species desiccates rapidly when removed from shaded situations, and will be highly sensitive to increased temperatures resulting from removal of shade-providing vegetation (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species appeared to be very common at the type locality, where Karunarathna et al. (2019) recorded 21 geckos per man-hour across seven localities over an area of 25 ha.
range: This species is known only from Kumaradola, Maragalakanda, Monaragala District in Sri Lanka's Uva Province, at elevations of 421 to 437 m asl (Karunarathna et al. 2019). The broader Maragalakanda area covers an area of 4,100 ha and an altitudinal range from 354 to 750 m asl (Karunarathna et al. 2019).
useTrade: There is no known or likely use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Habitat protection and restoration is urgently required, as this species will not tolerate higher temperatures in cleared areas. There is a proposed management plan for this area, which has been designated as an environmental protection area but with no associated enforcement. Formal enforcement of this status is required. Research is needed to clarify the ecology of this species and monitor population trends.

rationale: This species occurs in the Upper Fly system of Papua New Guinea and the Digul of Papua Province, Indonesia. It has been impacted by the Ok Tedi mine, with an estimated loss of 20-25% of the population in the Ok Tedi catchment from mine waste since the opening of the mine in 1983. The current known range of this species is relatively restricted, with an extent of occurrence of around 10,000 km<sup>2</sup>, but the number of locations is uncertain as it occurs in a number of tributary creeks with diverse threats including pollution from human settlements and invasive species. It is likely that more than 50% of occurrences are impacted by threats from human settlements such as from domestic and agricultural pollution, so there are probably ongoing declines in habitat quality. This species is therefore assessed as Near Threatened, as if current threats intensify this species would qualify for a threatened category. The identity of the specimens in the Digul also need verification.
habitat: This species occurs in both turbid lowland rivers and small, clear mountain tributaries between elevations of about 50-600 m. It is most commonly encountered in high elevations in rocky streams with variable flow in mountainous terrain. It can reach a maximum size of 13.5 cm SL (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2019).
threats: This species will have been impacted in the mainstream of the Ok Tedi by mine waste. Growing populations of people along tributary creeks pose a threat from expanding gardens, domestic waste and use of drinking water in the Upper Fly. There is also oil and gas exploration and production which could potentially threaten the creek habitat of this species. Invasive species such as snakeheads (Channidae) have been recorded in the area which could potentially threaten this species. Landslides, if they occur, would impact individual creek communities of this species. In the Digul the threats to this species are unknown.
population: There were five records of this species in 2011, with three in tributary creeks of the Ok Tedi river, one in the upper Fly, and one in the Ok Mart in lowland tributaries, with between 1-10 individuals collected at each site. In 2015-2018 this species occurred at 3 sites, including one tributary of the Ok Tedi with more than 20 individuals, and two tributaries in the headwaters of the Digul, with one site with between 1-10 individuals and the other with >20 (A.
